courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Foundations in Financial Accounting

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03

courses.description: This course develops students' conceptual skills and competence in processing, preparing and reporting accounting information in accordance with Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP). It introduces the basic concepts and principles of financial accounting including the analysis, recording and reporting of business transactions; preparation and interpretation of financial statements. Topics include the accounting principles, the recording process, accounting for assets, liabilities, net income and shareholders' equity; and decision making using accounting information.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ACCT2111.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
(1) understand the GAAP underlying the preparation and presentation of financial statements.
(2) apply the appropriate accounting concepts and principles to the recognition and measurement relating to revenues, expenses, assets, liabilities and equity.
(3) undertake the work involved in the recording, processing, summarising and reporting phases of the accounting cycle.
(4) prepare financial statements (statement of financial position, statement of comprehensive income and statement of changes in equity).
(5) appreciate the role and importance of financial accounting information in assisting decision-making in a business context.
(6) apply basic analytical tools to analyse, interpret and report on financial statements.
(7) communicate their analysis and findings in an effective way.
courses.course_syllabus: This course develops students’ conceptual skills and competence in processing, preparing and reporting accounting information in accordance with Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP). It introduces the basic concepts and principles of financial accounting including the analysis, recording and reporting of business transactions; preparation and interpretation of financial statements. Topics include the accounting principles, the recording process, accounting for assets, liabilities, net income and shareholders’ equity; and decision making using accounting information.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are welcomed to sen their comments/feedback to the course instructor via email or appointment. CTE will be collected at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: Weygandt, Kimmel and Kieso, Financial Accounting: A Focus on Fundamentals, John Wiley, latest edition.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Introductory Financial Accounting
courses.description: This course is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of financial accounting principles, practices and its underlying theories. In this course, we will emphasize on basic financial accounting concepts and principles, and discuss how to measure a company's net income, assets, liabilities and shareholders' equity using Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP).
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ACCT1111
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students should be able to:
(1) understand the accounting concepts and procedures, and to apply them to the business world
(2) develop skills and increase their ability to solve problems that they will need to succeed in a business environment
(3) learn the technology that allows them access to numerous online materials relating the real world of accounting and business
(4) learn how to study and manage their own tasks that will help them acquire further knowledge on their own
courses.course_syllabus: This course is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of financial accounting principles, practices and its underlying theories. In this course, we will emphasize on basic financial accounting concepts and principles, and discuss how to measure company’s net income, assets, liabilities and shareholders’ equity using Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP). In addition, we will also introduce briefly the development of accounting standards, the international accounting standards (IFRS) and some of the major differences between the GAAP and IFRS.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are welcomed to provide comments and feedback to the instructor via email, appointment, and CTE exercise.
courses.required_readings:
Weygandt, Kimmel and Kieso, Financial Accounting, John Wiley, 6th edition, 2010 with IFRS Update.
ISBN 978-0-470-62327-5
courses.recommended_readings: Jeffrey Waybright, and Robert Kemp, Financial Accounting, Pearson, 2010. ISBN 978-0-13-706779-4

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Introductory Management Accounting
courses.description: This course is designed to provide students with the concepts and techniques of managerial accounting, with the emphasis on the uses of management accounting information by managers in planning, controlling and decisions making. Major topics will include costing systems, activity-based costing, cost-volume-profit relationship, variable costing, budgeting, standard costing, and relevant costs for decision-making.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: ACCT1111 or ACCT2111
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
(1) Understand the management accounting concepts and apply the knowledge to both manufacturing and service companies.
(2) Use the information from management accounting systems to improve the competitiveness of the companies in operational excellence, product leadership, and customer service.
(3) Develop skills and ability to solve problems that they will need to succeed in a business environment.
(4) Learn how to study and manage their own tasks that will help them acquire further knowledge on their own.
courses.course_syllabus: This course is an introduction to managerial accounting. It is designed to provide students the concepts and techniques of managerial accounting, with the emphasis on the uses of management accounting information by managers in planning, controlling, and decisions making. The course emphasizes the links between accounting information and management activities such as strategic and operational decision making, financial planning and control, organizational design, and performance evaluation. Major topics will include costing systems, activity-based costing, cost-volume-profit relationship, variable costing, budgeting, standard costing and relevant costs for decision making.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are welcomed to provide comments and feedback to the instructor via email, appointment, and CTE exercise.
courses.required_readings:
Horngren, Data, Foster, Rajan, & Ittner, Cost Accounting – A managerial emphasis, Pearson, 13th edition – the main textbook.
Weygandt, Kimmel, & Kieso, Financial Accounting, Wiley, 6th edition (2010 IFRS update) – for the cash flow statement part only.
courses.recommended_readings: Garrison, Noreen & Brewer, Managerial Accounting, McGraw Hill, 12th edition (International edition).

courses.description: This course seeks to provide an introduction to the legal environment in the business context. To this end, the course will begin with an examination of the legal system of the Hong Kong SAR before proceeding to encompass a selection of topics in laws relating to business such as contract law, law of negligence, employment law, privacy law, laws of equal opportunities, anti-corruption law and anti-competition law. Students can know the important rules of business law. These rules concern how the courts deal with business-related disputes in the real life and students can in particular learn issues about consumers’ rights and to what extent the laws enhance a fair business environment.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ACCT3151
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students will be able to:

(1) have effective written communication skills

(2) acquire the knowledge of selected important rules of / relating to business law

(3) integrate relevant legal knowledge into business decision making

(4) apply the relevant rules to analyze and solve problems in a business setting
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics covered:

1. The legal system of the Hong Kong SAR

2. Contract Law: introduction to formation of contracts, contract terms relating to consumer protection and the Trade Description Ordinance, misrepresentation and remedies for breach of contract

3. Law of Negligence

4. Employment Law

5. Laws of equal opportunities

6. Privacy law

7. Anti-competition law
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are warmly welcomed to send their comments/ feedback to the course instructor. The channels include: (1) e-mails to the instructor; (2) appointment with the instructor; and (3) formal CTE exercise.
courses.required_readings:
Textbook

D.K. Srivastava, ed., Business Law in Hong Kong (Hong Kong: Sweet & Maxwell Asia, 5th ed., 2017)
courses.recommended_readings:
Major References

Relevant information in the website as stated in each topic of the course materials, including:

- ‘overview of the labour legislation’ (http://www.labour.gov.hk/eng/legislat/contentA.htm) and ‘FAQ’ (http://www.labour.gov.hk/eng/faq/content.htm) in the website of the Labour Department of the HKSAR

- The website of the Privacy Commissioner on Personal Data on ‘Data Privacy Law’ (https://www.pcpd.org.hk/english/data\_privacy\_law/ordinance\_at\_a\_Glance/ordinance.html) and ‘Compliance and Enforcement’ (https://www.pcpd.org.hk/english/enforcement/commissioners\_findings/investigation\_reports/invest\_report.html )

- The website of the Equal Opportunities Commission on ‘Discrimination Legislation’ (http://www.eoc.org.hk/)

- The website of the Independent Commission Against Corruption on ‘Landmark Cases’ (http://www.icac.org.hk/en/law\_enforcement/lc/ci/index.html#jewellery)

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Business Ethics and Entrepreneurship
courses.description: This course is designed to provide students with an opportunity to study independently start-ups and existing businesses in Hong Kong and the Mainland. Through this course, students learn to (i) integrate and apply their knowledge acquired from different areas and (ii) appreciate how strategies, innovation, corporate social responsibility and business ethics play a role in the development of a business model which adds values to business.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: ACCT2111
courses.course_syllabus: Student-oriented teaching (STOT) is a small group, less structured teaching which relates to the student’s major field but not necessarily ties to any particular course. This course is designed to provide students with an opportunity to study independently on some selected business and ethical issues in Hong Kong and the PRC. Through this course students learn to integrate and apply their knowledge acquired from different areas.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are welcomed to provide comments and feedback to the instructor via email and appointment.
courses.required_readings: N/A
courses.recommended_readings:
“Code of Ethics for Professional Accountants” is revised in July 2015 by the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants in the volume I of members’ handbook.
(Download from HKICPA website: http://app1.hkicpa.org.hk/ebook/main.php)

(Download from International Federation of Accountants (IFAC) website: http://www.ifac.org)

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Accounting Practicum and Fieldwork
courses.description: This course is designed to provide students with professional knowledge and experiences in real-life environment. Practicum and non-local fieldwork/training programs will be arranged to help students link theoretical knowledge to business practices. Students should submit two written reports on the internship experience and the training programme respectively. These reports address topics such as comparative studies of business practices, practical problems encountered in work environment, ethics and corporate social responsibilities. In addition, performance feedback from employer will form part of the assessment.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ACCT3001
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students are expected to be able to:
1. integrate and apply theoretical knowledge and skills acquired to real-world business environment
2. be aware of the importance of business ethics and responsibilities that individuals and companies must assume in business and society
3. understand differences in business practices and culture
4. communicate effectively and efficiently in a professional way
5. explore career options, and gain general work experience
courses.course_syllabus: Practicum and non-local fieldwork/training programs will be arranged to help students link theoretical knowledge to business practices. Students should submit two written reports on the internship experience and the training programme respectively. These reports address topics such as comparative studies of business practices, practical problems encountered in work environment, ethics and corporate social responsibilities.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Revised course questionnaire
Tailored questionnaire
Reflection of teachers(including evidence from assessment)
courses.required_readings: N/A

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Professional Seminar Series
courses.description: The professional seminars are designed to provide students with an opportunity to meet industry leaders so as to keep abreast of the current development in the accounting and business professions and to explore different career opportunities. Through these seminars, students are expected to have a more in-depth reflection on some current accounting and business issues. Topics of the seminars may range from financial reporting, cost and management accounting, business assurance, taxation to other current business and ethical issues.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By completion of the course, students are expected to be able to:
- keep abreast of the current development in the accounting and business professions;
- have an in-depth reflection on some current accounting and business issues; and
- understand more about various career opportunities in the accounting and business professions.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics of the seminars may range from financial reporting, cost and management accounting, business assurance, taxation to other current business and ethical issues.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are welcomed to provide comments and feedback to the instructor via email and appointment.
courses.required_readings: N/A

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Accounting Practicum and Experiential Learning
courses.description: This course is designed to provide students with professional knowledge and experiences in real-life business environment. Students are expected to link theoretical knowledge to business practices in a global context through practicum and various training programmes.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completion of this course, students are expected to be able to:
CLO1 integrate and apply theoretical knowledge and skills developed in various courses to real-world business
CLO2 understand differences in culture and business styles of different regions
CLO3 demonstrate good team skills and leadership ability
CLO4 able to communicate effectively and efficiently in a professional way
courses.course_syllabus: Training programs and enrichment activities include: study trip, internship, case training workshops, leadership and team building workshops, mentorship program, community service, etc.
courses.feedback_evaluation: The course leader will meet students regularly and receive feedback from students during the whole training period. Course evaluation will be conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: Cases will be provided to students at the case training workshops whereas required reading is not applicable for other enrichment activities.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Accounting Field Study and Experiential Learning
courses.description: The course is designed to expose students to a wide spectrum of global accounting related issues in a non-local business environment. Students will take a residential programme in countries or regions outside Hong Kong. Course learning activities may include lectures at universities, case projects, seminars and discussions with local accounting professionals and/or government officials, and site visits to enterprises.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completion of this course, students are expected to be able to:
CLO1 understand accounting practices and business culture in a global environment
CLO2 understand the operation of one or more functional areas of different enterprises and the roles of accounting
CLO3 communicate effectively and efficiently in a professional way
courses.course_syllabus:
(1) Classroom lectures
Students will take classroom lectures at universities in the visiting countries and regions. The purpose of classroom lectures is to help students understand local and/or global accounting standards, practices and issues.

(2) Group case project
Students will be required to study business models of the enterprises they will visit and present their findings to the class. The purpose of the group case project is to help students better understand the enterprises and relevant industries, and learn more about the roles of accounting in businesses.

(3) Visits to enterprises
Visits to enterprises will be arranged. Through these visits, students have chances to know about the operating process, accounting practices and business cultures of real-world enterprises. They also have chances to talk to the management of those enterprises.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are warmly welcomed to provide comments/feedback on the course by sending e-mails to the course instructor and/or making appointments with the course instructor.
courses.required_readings: Reading materials will be provided by the teacher according to the field study.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Financial Reporting I
courses.description: This course is designed to augment the knowledge of students who have had instruction in the fundamentals of accounting. To this end, it will provide instruction in accounting theory, the development of accounting principles and their application to income determination, the presentation of financial statements for business, and the management and reporting of assets as well as liabilities.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: ACCT2111
courses.learning_outcomes:
(1) To learn and evaluate current principles of financial accounting.
(2) To apply generally accepted accounting principles to situations involving the recording of transactions and the preparation of financial statements.
(3) To read and critically evaluate financial statements.
(4) To consider the larger context of financial reporting (beyond rules and procedures), including how company executives and financial analysts view financial reporting.
courses.course_syllabus: Accounting theory, development of accounting principles and their applications to income determination and presentation of financial statements for business firms are covered in the course. Measurement and reporting of Assets, Current liabilities and Revenue Recognition are thoroughly discussed. Different applications of accounting rules to the Hong Kong environment are introduced.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Your comments and feedback are welcome addressed to the instructor or teaching assistant any time in the semester through e-mail or personal meeting.
courses.required_readings: Intermediate Accounting, Bazley, Nikolai and Jones, 11th edition, South-Western Publishing Company
courses.recommended_readings:
Reference Book
Intermediate Accounting, Kieso, Weygandt and Warfield, 12th edition, Wiley

HKICPA website
http://www.hkicpa.org.hk

Solution Manual
A set of solution manual will be reserved in library for your convenience. You can check answers after you have practiced the chapter-end questions, exercises, problems.

China Telecommunication Industry Case
China Telecommunication is a listed company in Hong Kong. This case study is to help students to apply various accounting concepts learned in this course to real-world business situations. The case allows students to explore various issues associated with asset valuation. Based on information contained in the case, every student required to develop a critical analysis of the valuation of receivables, fixed assets and intangible assets and submit a written report.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Financial Reporting II
courses.description: This course, a continuation of ACCT3111, will emphasize on stock-holders' equity and such other special accounting items as inflation accounting, leases, pensions and other post-employment benefits, accounting changes, and the more sophisticated aspects of financial reporting.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: ACCT3111
courses.course_syllabus: This course is a continuation of Financial Reporting I with particular emphasis on stockholders’ equity and other special topics, such as, accounting for pensions, leases, income taxes as well as accounting changes and errors. The different applications of accounting rules to the Hong Kong environment are introduced.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Your comments or feedbacks related to the course are welcome. Please feel free to send comments to me (if any) by email or contact the instructor directly.
courses.required_readings: Intermediate Accounting, Bazley, Nikolai and Jones, 11th edition, South-Western Publishing Company
courses.recommended_readings:
(1) Intermediate Accounting, Kieso, Weygandt and Warfield, 13th edition, Wiley

(2) Members’ Handbook, Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants

‘Code of Ethics for Professional Accountants’ issued by the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants in the Volume I of members’ handbook and updated to December 2010. (HKICPA website: http://www.hkicpa.org.hk/ebook/main.php)

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Cost and Management Accounting

Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04

courses.description: This course emphasizes the analysis and the use of cost accounting information for managers' decision-making. The major topics covered will include ABC costing, cost allocation for joint products and byproducts, cost estimation and learning curve, relevant costs analysis,master and capital budgeting, variances analysis, inventory costing method and inventory management.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: ACCT2121
courses.learning_outcomes:
On completion of this course, students are expected to be able to:
1. Understand key managerial accounting concepts of an intermediate-level course
2. Apply management accounting concepts and techniques to solve problems in a business context
3. Communicate their analyses and findings in an effective way
courses.course_syllabus: To be a successful professional accountant or business manager, you need to know how to use accounting information to do planning, controlling and evaluating. This course emphasizes the analysis and use of cost accounting information for Managers' decision-making. Major topics include process costing, capacity analysis, overhead variance analysis, pricing decisions, performance measurement, cost allocation and capital budgeting.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are welcomed to provide comments and feedback to the instructor via email, appointment, and CTE exercise.
courses.required_readings:
1. Required textbook: Horngren/Datar/Foster/Rajan/Ittner “Cost Accounting – A Managerial Emphasis”, 13th Edition. Pearson Education, Inc.

2. Cases and articles are provided in class to facilitate students’ understanding of relevant concepts and techniques.

3. All course materials will be distributed in class or posted on WebCT.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Contemporary Accounting Information Systems

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04

courses.description: This course will provide a framework for students to understand the functions of accounting information systems in contemporary business organizations. System documentation skills will be introduced to enable students to fully understand a company’s business processes and its internal controls. In addition, students will learn how to build accounting information system in a database management system environment using data modeling techniques. The course will be supplemented by laboratory sessions.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. Pre-requisite: ACCT2111
2. Not for students who have taken ACCT3141
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Understanding information system
- Introduction to AIS
- Enterprise System / E-business
2. Organizing and managing information
- Documenting information system
- REA data modeling approach
- Build AIS and application controls using MS Access
3. Enterprise risk management and business processes
- COSO/COBIT internal control framework
- General organization and IT controls
- Business process control plans
4. Reporting and other issues
- Contemporary IT issues, XBRL, SDLC, etc
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students are encouraged to provide comments or feedbacks to teacher during the course. Interim course survey may be conducted on a need basis (e.g. new teaching activities / methods).

Students’ feedbacks are obtained from course teaching evaluation (CTE) conducted at term end. Teacher will base on CTE and assessment results to evaluate own teaching effectiveness and identify areas of improvement in future.
courses.required_readings: N/A
courses.recommended_readings:
Accounting Information Systems, 8th Edition, Gelinas and Dull, Thomson, 2010. (Text)

Enterprise Information Systems - A Pattern-based Approach, 3rd Edition, Dunn, Cherrington and Hollander, McGraw-Hill, 2005. (Reference)

Building Accounting Systems Using Access 2007, 7th Ed., Perry and Newmark, Thomson, 2010. (Reference)

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Business Law
courses.description: This course will provide an introduction to the legal system of Hong Kong with emphasis on the legal environment of business. It will encompass a study of selected topics in contract law including the elements of business contracting, the rights and obligations of parties to the contract, the sale of goods and employment law. This course will also examine the tort of negligence in a professional context.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ACCT2151, LAWS1041 or LAWS1042
courses.learning_outcomes: Students can know the important rules of business law at the end of the course. These rules concern how the courts deal with business-related disputes in the real life. As many of the rules are designed to protect consumers, students can in particular know more about consumers’ rights. In addition, they can learn more analytical skills and writing skills which can help them to apply the rules to do their assessments.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course seeks to provide an introduction to the institutions, doctrines and methodology of the law in the business context. To this end, the course will begin with an examination of the legal system of the Hong Kong SAR before proceeding to encompass a selection of topics in business law such as the law relating to contract, torts, agency, employment and the sale of goods.

The legal system of the Hong Kong SAR

The Basic Law, legislation, common law, equity and the court system

Contract law

Formation of contracts (offer, acceptance, intention to create legal relations, consideration and formality), contract terms and exemption clauses, vitiating factors (misrepresentation, undue influence, illegality and unconscionable contracts), discharge of contracts (performance, agreement and frustration) and the remedies for breach of contract (damages, rescission, injunction and specific performance)

Employment law

Employees / independent contractors and the rights of employees

Torts law

Negligence

Agency law

Teh rights and duties of agens, authority of agents

Sale of goods law

Important rules under the Sale of Goods Ordinance
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are warmly welcome to send email messages to teachers if they have any comment or feedback on the course.
courses.required_readings:
D.K. Srivastava, ed., Business Law in Hong Kong (Hong Kong: Sweet & Maxwell Asia, 2nd ed., 2007)

Anne Carver, Hong Kong Business Law (Hong Kong: Longman, 6th ed., 2004)
courses.recommended_readings:
K. Arjunan & A. Majid, Business Law in Hong Kong (Hong Kong: LexisNexis, 2002)

Andy Chiu et al, Introduction to Hong Kong Business Law (Singapore: Prentice Hall, 2001)

Cheng Po Wah, et al, Hong Kong Business Law (Hong Kong: The Hong Kong Association of Accounting Technicians, 2002)

Vanessa Stott, An Introduction to Hong Kong Business Law (Hong Kong: Longman, 3rd ed., 2001)

Relevant chapter of textbooks are stated at the end of each topic of the course materials for students’ learning purposes.

Relevant web information is provided in topic 1 of the course materials.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Company Law

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03

courses.description: This course is designed to acquaint students with the principles of modern company law in Hong Kong and to increase their awareness of the legal issues which are of interest to the commercial community. It will examine the formation of companies, the effects of incorporation, the division of powers as between the various organs of the company, its relationship with outsiders, key differences in methods of fund raising, options available to companies in financial difficulties and the role of external regulatory bodies.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. Prerequisite: ACCT3151
2. Not for students who have taken LAWS2101 & LAWS2102
courses.learning_outcomes: By the end of the course, students will be able to better appreciate the relevance of the legal principles as they apply to modern commercial transactions that are undertaken through the conduit of a company. In addition, students will be apprised of the development of company law in Hong Kong as the government undertakes the Companies Ordinance Rewrite with the objective of enacting a more user friendly and modern regime.
courses.course_syllabus: This course is designed to acquaint the student with the principles of modern company law in Hong Kong. Issues to be examined include the formation of companies, the consequence and effects of incorporation, the division of powers between the various organs of the company, its relationship with outsiders, key differences in methods of fund raising, options available to companies in financial difficulty and the role of external regulatory bodies.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are welcomed to provide comments and feedback to the instructor via email, appointment, and CTE exercise.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Taxation

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01

courses.description: This course will discuss the basic principles of the Hong Kong taxation system. The topics covered will include salaries tax, property tax, profits tax, personal allowances, personal assessment, stamp duty and estate duty.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: ACCT3111
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the courses, students will be able to
(1) understand the basic rules of Hong Kong Taxation,
(2) compute the tax payable under different taxes, and
(3) develop basic tax planning techniques
courses.course_syllabus:
This course will discuss the basic principles of the Hong Kong taxation system. Major topics include salaries tax, property tax, profits tax, personal allowances, personal assessment, and stamp duty.

1. Introduction to the Hong Kong taxation system (Chapter 1)
2. Property Tax (Chapter 6)
3. Salaries tax: scope of charge (Chapter 2)
4. Salaries tax: income from office and employment (Chapter 3)
5. Salaries tax: expenses and deductions, personal allowances and tax computation (Chapter 4)
6. Salaries tax Part IV: husband and wife (Chapter 5)
7. Personal assessment (Chapter 19)
8. Profits tax :scope of charge and meaning of trade (Chapter 9 and chapter 10)
9. Profits tax : receipts (Chapter 11)
10. Profits tax : expenditures (Chapter 12)
11. Profits tax: computation of assessable profit (Chapter 13)
12. Stamp duty (Chapter 20)
13. Objections and appeals (Chapter 8)

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Introduction to Python for Business and Accounting Analytics
courses.description: This introductory course offers a foundational understanding of Python programming as applied in business and accounting analytics. It covers Python programming basics, focusing on data processing and effective visualization techniques relevant to business and financial data. The course emphasizes Python's core elements, including essential syntax, control structures, and methods for managing and analyzing complex, unstructured datasets. Students will engage in practical exercises designed to cultivate skills in utilizing Python for efficient data manipulation, supporting business decision-making and analytics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite(s): ENGG1003
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:

1. Understand the basics of Python programming logic.
2. Grasp how Python can be applied in the fields of accounting and finance.
3. Conduct basic data processing and cleaning using Python.
4. Create simple visualizations of financial data with Python tools.
5. Apply Python programming skills to assist in basic business decision-making.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to Python in Accounting and Finance
2. Python Programming Basics for Beginners
3. Essential Python Syntax and Control Structures
4. Python Functions, Modules, and Basic Libraries
5. Data Types and Collection Manipulation in Python
6. Basic Data Processing and Cleaning Techniques
7. Introduction to Data Visualization with Python
8. Fundamentals of Financial Data Analysis in Python
9. Handling Unstructured Financial Data in Python
10. Introduction to Financial Forecasting with Python
11. Exploring Python in Crowdsourced Data Analysis
12. Python in Corporate Decision-Making Processes
13. Basics of Machine Learning in Finance with Python
14. Emerging Trends in Python for Accounting and Analytics
courses.feedback_evaluation: CTE will be conducted at the end of the course
courses.required_readings: N/A
courses.recommended_readings: Shaw, Z. A. (2017). *Learn python 3 the hard way: A very simple introduction to the terrifyingly beautiful world of computers and code*. Addison-Wesley Professional.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Capstone Project: Business Ethics and Entrepreneurship
courses.description: This course is designed to provide students with a capstone experience to study independently start-ups and existing businesses in Hong Kong and the Mainland. Through this course, students learn to (i) integrate and apply their knowledge acquired from different areas; (ii) reflect the importance of corporate social responsibility and business ethics of being a professional accountant; and (iii) appreciate how strategies and innovation play a role in the development of a business model which adds values to business. Such capstone experience aims at helping students transit to the practical business environment.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: ACCT3121
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Real-life company analysis
2. Business plan on a hypothetical business scenario
3. Current ethical issues in relation to business and/or accounting practices
courses.feedback_evaluation: This is a student-oriented project so no formal CTE will be done. However, course teacher will meet students regularly and receive feedback from them throughout the term.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Advanced Financial Accounting Studies
courses.description: This course deals with advanced topics of financial accounting. It examines the accounting principles and standards related to group reporting, non-corporate entities as well as other issues. Major topics include business combinations, consolidated financial statements, intragroup transactions, associates, joint ventures and foreign currency translation. This course also contributes to students’ undergraduate capstone experience by helping them (1) integrate business knowledge and generic skills; (2) think from the perspective of a professional and ethical accountant; and (3) transition to the real-world business environment.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: ACCT3112
courses.course_syllabus:
This course is a continuation of financial reporting and deals with the more advanced aspects of financial accounting. The course assumes knowledge acquired in previous financial reporting courses and thereby focuses on the exploration of the core technical capabilities to prepare and analyse financial reports for combined entities. It takes the subject into greater depth and contextualises the role of accountant as a professional financial adviser by examining the group reporting requirements as well as the rationales behind various accounting principles and standards relating to group reporting.

This course attempts to investigate issues relating to group reporting and therefore includes such topics as business combinations, consolidations of subsidiaries, intragroup transactions and foreign currency translation. Special problems in the consolidation of corporate financial statements will also be covered in the course.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are encouraged to provide feedback on the course. Feedback can be sent to the instructor through either email or message system in the eLearning platform at any time or made an appointment with the instructor. Formal teaching evaluation exercise will also be performed at the end of the semester.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Advanced Financial Accounting
courses.description: This course will deal with the more advanced aspect of financial accounting. Major topics covered will include partnership formation, dissolution and liquidation, mergers and acquisitions, business combinations, equity and cost methods of accounting for subsidiaries, inter-company profit and loss adjustments, special problems in the consolidation of corporate financial statements and foreign currency translation. The different applications of accounting rules to the Hong Kong environment are introduced.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: ACCT3112
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students will be able to:
1. Summarise the different types of business combination and key accounting issues
2. Account for the different types of business combination
3. Understand the differences between the cost method and equity method of accounting
4. Comprehend and explain the need for and the nature of consolidated financial statements
5. Understand and apply the acquisition method and merger method of accounting
6. Account for and eliminate intragroup transactions
7. Prepare consolidated financial statements for groups with subsidiaries and associates
8. Account for foreign currency translation and foreign subsidiaries
courses.course_syllabus: This course is a continuation of financial reporting and deals with the more advanced aspects of financial accounting. Topics covered are: mergers and acquisitions, business combinations, equity and cost methods of accounting for subsidiaries and associates, intragroup profit and loss adjustments, special problems in the consolidation of corporate financial statements and foreign currency translation. The different applications of accounting rules to the Hong Kong environment are covered.

courses.description: This course is designed to provide students with the fundamentals of auditing. Major topics include an overview of auditing functions, professional ethics, auditors' legal liability, generally accepted auditing standards, audit planning, internal controls evaluation, detailed audit tests, audit sampling, audit evidence evaluation, determination of audit opinion, and preparation of auditors' reports. Computerized audit software will be introduced in the course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: ACCT3111
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:

1. describe the demands for auditing in response to changing market dynamics

2. explain fundamental auditing concepts and apply basic techniques in performing the audit

3. develop more mutual professional judgment, a vital skill in today’s auditing environment

4. understand professional ethics and auditor responsibilities
courses.course_syllabus: This course is designed to provide students with the fundamentals of auditing. Major topics include an overview of auditing functions, professional ethics, basic concepts underlying the audit process: materiality, audit risk, and evidence, the generally accepted auditing standards, audit planning, demands of Sarbanes-Oxley, internal controls evaluation, detailed audit tests, audit sampling, determination of audit opinion, and preparation of auditors’ reports.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Accounting Information in Capital Market
courses.description: This course establishes a framework for evaluating accounting choices and categorizing the strength of authority for particular accounting treatments. This is accomplished by exposing the students to empirical accounting research and by creating an awareness of the endogenous factors affecting accounting decisions. Major themes are the integration of cash flow and accrual based measures of income from a theoretical perspective and the synthesis of accounting choice questions based on the asset valuation versus income measurement dichotomy. The end result will be a deeper understanding of both the structure and the process of accounting policy-making.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: ACCT3111
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:

(1) Identify theories that shape accounting,

(2) Explain predicted accounting behavior based on underlying theories

(3) Critically analyze controversial accounting issues.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to Accounting Information in Capital Markets

2. Accounting under Ideal Conditions

3. Decision Usefulness Approach to Financial Reporting

4. Efficient Capital Market

5. The Information Approach to Decision Usefulness

6. The Measurement Approach to Decision Usefulness

7. Measurement Application

8. Economic Consequences and Positive Accounting Theory

9. An Analysis on Conflict of Interest

10. Executive Compensation

11. Earnings Management

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: China Business Valuation and Analysis
courses.description: The primary objective of this course is to investigate in depth the current issues in analysing financial statements of Chinese listed firms. It will focus on the analysis of the impact of institutional factors on financial statements, including accounting standard setting, auditing practice, legal and corporate governance, and stock market development. It will examine in depth managerial incentive in accounting choice and estimates. The course will also utilize modern tools and techniques of financial statement analysis through cases assignments and discussions in class.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: ACCT3111
courses.learning_outcomes: By the end of the course, students should be able to use financial statement data to measure the value of companies in China.
courses.course_syllabus: This course introduces students to issues in business valuation and analysis. It integrates theories and practices of accounting, economics, finance and strategy. A brief discussion of economic determinants and valuation implications of accounting, standard setting, auditing and corporate governance is followed by the examination of economic motivations and valuation implication of corporate decisions including accounting strategy, disclosure strategy, financing strategy, investment strategy and restructuring strategy.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Financial Statement Analysis and Valuation

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03

courses.description: The objective of this course is to present a comprehensive and up-to-date treatment of the analysis of financial statement as an aid to decision-making by managers, creditors and shareholders. It will evaluate the properties of accounting policies and estimates of a firm and will assess a firm's performance using tools such as ratio analysis and cash flow analysis. The role of accounting information in capital market and contracting process will also be examined. Students are expected to complete a project analysing the financial statements of companies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: 1. Prerequisite: ACCT3112 or permission from instructor
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course students should have answers to the following questions:

• How are fundamental values (or “intrinsic values”) estimated?

• How are business strategies analyzed in order to understand the value they create?

• How is “value created for shareholders” identified?

• How does one pull apart the financial statements to get at the relevant information for valuing equities?

• What is the relevance of cash-flows? Of dividends? Of earnings? Of book values?

• How does one handle the imprecision in valuation models?

• How does ratio analysis help in valuation?

• How does reverse engineering work in stock selection?

• How does profitability tie into valuation?

• What is growth? How does one analyze growth? How does one value a growth firm?

• How does one analyze the quality of financial reports?

• How does one deal with the accounting methods used in financial statements?

• How is financial analysis developed for strategy and planning?

• What determines a firm's P/E ratio? How does one calculate what the P/E should be?

• What determines a firm's market-to-book (P/B) ratio? How does one calculate what the P/B should be?

• How does one evaluate risk? For equity? For debt?

• How does one evaluate an equity research report?

• How does one trade on fundamental information?
courses.course_syllabus:
This course is about the analysis of financial information - particularly firms’ financial statements - for making decisions to invest in businesses. The primary focus is on equity (share) valuation. When buying a share in a firm, the investor wants to know what a reasonable price is to pay: What is the firm worth? The course explains how he or she answers that question by analyzing information. As financial statements contain considerable information about firms, the course involves financial tatement analysis. The methods of fundamental analysis will be covered in detail and applied in cases and projects involving

listed companies. Topics include models of shareholder value, a comparison of accrual accounting and discounted cash flow approaches to valuation, reverse engineering methods of stock selection, the analysis of profitability, growth and aluation generation in a firm, diagnosing accounting quality, forecasting earnings and cash flows, pro-forma analysis for strategy and planning, and the determination of price/earnings and market-to-book ratios. The course does not “assume market efficiency.” Rather, it develops the techniques for challenging traded prices in order to assess whether investments are appropriately priced.

Content, highlighting fundamental concepts

The course will be taught with a view to designing techniques to be used in an (independent) equity research department or firm. Accordingly, the material is of particular interest to buyand sell- side equity analyst who must issue a buy, hold or sell recommendations on stocks. However, much of the material covered in the course is also relevant to the corporate financial analyst and for private equity analysis, for evaluating acquisitions, restructurings and other investments, and for calculating the value generated by strategic scenarios. By the end of the course, the student should feel competent in writing a thorough, credible equity research report or investment analysis that meets the highest standards of professionalism. The course is of interest to those contemplating careers in investment banking (particularly in the equity area), security analysis, consulting, private equity, public accounting, and corporate finance. And it will also help with personal investing. The course will be in the form of lectures, discussions, exercises, and cases, and will involve a course project.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Strategic Management Accounting
courses.description: This is an advanced course in management accounting examining the role of management accounting systems in strategy formation and implementation and as a potential source of sustainable competitive advantage. The course will provide students with practical exposure to the issues involved in the design and implementation of these systems. It will also explore the structures, tools and procedures available to managers to help motivate, evaluate and reward members of the organization.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: ACCT3121
courses.course_syllabus:
This is an advanced course in management accounting examining the role of management accounting and control systems in ensuring that the organization’s strategies and plans are carried out. Major topics include management control systems, transfer pricing, performance measurement, incentive compensation systems, and corporate governance.

The objectives of this course are to:

1. Provide students with basic concepts of management control systems;

2. Provide students with practical exposure to the design and implementation of various control structures and tools using management accounting.

This course does not deal with technical details of cost accounting as in ACCT2121 and ACCT3121. Instead, it focuses on applying management accounting in organization control. At a practical level, this course should be of interest to students planning a career in accounting, management consulting, or general management.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Forensic Accounting and Audit Analytics
courses.description: The advent of technology and data analytics is posing both opportunities and challenges to the accounting professions. On one hand, stakeholders are demanding a more relevant, efficient and meaningful audit of financial statements, driving the accounting profession to conduct the audit engagements using a more in-depth risk-based methodology. On the other hand, with the increasing incidents of fraud including cyberattacks, there has been a significant rise in the adoption of fraud examination and forensic analytics which is considered as a science used to proactively seek opportunities to prevent and detect fraud, waste and abuse by levering information in corporate data assets. This course combines academic and practical discussions of the following three important interlocking areas, namely, how to utilise analytics in an audit of financial statements, how a fraud examination should be carried out and how companies should respond to cyber risks.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisites: ACCT4131
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics include:

(1) An introduction of Audit Analytics and Risk-based Methodology in Financial Audits

(2) Use of Computer-assisted Auditing Techniques (CAATs): Checking for Completeness and Integrity, Search for duplicates and gaps and Data Profiling

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Accounting Data Analytics for Business
courses.description: This course is set up for accounting students who would like to rise to the challenges and opportunities that “big data” may present to the profession and are interested in getting hands-on experience with data analytics. The course will introduce the foundations of data science and discuss the potential implications of “big data” on the accounting profession. With hands-on data analytic exercises incorporated into the learning process, the course will provide a basis for handling and analyzing large-scale data stored within and outside an organization as well as generating business insights from analyses.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Pre-requisite(s):
1. ACCT3241
2.,DSME2011 or DOTE2011
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking the course, students should:
(1) Understand the basic concepts and techniques for data analytics
(2) Learn to approach business problems data-analytically
(3) Be able to choose the appropriate tools and methods for different data analysis tasks at hand and implement simple tasks in data analysis, with an understanding of their limitations
(4) Be capable of interacting competently on the topic of data analytics and collaborating with other colleagues in a data analysis project
(5) Be prepared to deal with new trends in analytics techniques affecting businesses and seize the future opportunities brought by “big data” to the accounting profession
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics:
1. Introduction & Basic Statistics
2. Tools for Data Analytics
3. Lab Sessions:
R / RapidMiner Studio / (Tableau)
4. Data Acquisition and Preprocessing
5. Data Exploration and Visualization
6. Basic Descriptive Analytics
7. Basic Predictive Analytics
8. More on Causal Inference
8. Accounting Models from Academic Research
10. More on Statistical Learning / Data Mining
11. Web Scraping and Textual Analysis
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are encouraged to provide feedback on the course. Feedback can be sent to the teaching assistant or the instructor through either email or message system in the eLearning platform at any time. Formal teaching evaluation exercise will also be performed at the end of the semester.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Data Visualization in Accounting
courses.description: Accounting can be benefited from the use of ‘big data’ to provide better support for judgmental conclusions regarding bad debts, warranties, estimates of useful lives and salvage values, etc. This course will be a hybrid of a survey of the framework of big data and its uses and the actual manipulation of the data using data analysis software such as Tableau. The course does not rely on a knowledge of computer programming nor deep comprehension of advanced statistical techniques. Rather, this course will be largely hands-on in familiarizing participants with the use of data analysis software. Students will select a business question of interest to explore, obtain the appropriate data set(s), and present conclusions derived from the data.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: ACCT3142
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, you should be able to:

(1) Explain how “big data” and “data visualization” can be used in business scenarios
(2) Refine a big data business scenarios into an accounting application of the information (tax, estimates of accruals, revenue projections and forecasting, etc.)
(3) Understand the choices available for visualization of data and differentiate amongst alternatives
(4) Form an analysis of the selected big data and present conclusions obtained in an appropriate visualization
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics included:
1. Overview of Big Data and Data Visualization; Numeric versus non-numeric
2. Design Principles for Effective Presentations; Identification of end users and best practices for effective visual presentations of data
3. Introduction to Analytics with Tableau; Dates, Tables, and Mapping; Selections of Charting Tools for Persuasiveness
4. Planning a “Big Data” presentation
5. Identifying Key Metrics and Indicators
6. Telling the data “story” with visuals and dashboards
7. Refining a project proposal to major influence points
8. Importing and Preparing raw data for analysis and presentation in Tableau
9. Exploratory analysis and dashboard submission for storyboards and storytelling
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are welcomed to send their comments/ feedback to the course instructor. The channels include: (1) e-mails to the instructor; (2) appointment with the instructor; and (3) formal CTE exercise.
courses.required_readings:
##### Learning source:

<https://www.tableau.com/support/knowledgebase>

<https://www.datacamp.com/community/tutorials/data-science-industry-infographic>

<https://www.ted.com/talks/hans_rosling_shows_the_best_stats_you_ve_ever_seen>
courses.recommended_readings:
There is no required textbook for this course. Textbooks in this area are frequently superceded almost as soon as they are published, therefore we will primarily utilize web-based resources. Most of the course materials are available online, free of charge. The software for Tableau is provided to the University via a site license from Tableau; an individual license for your personal computing device is also available free of charge via the University license.

The most frequently utilized source will be:
https://www.tableau.com/support/knowledgebase

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Blockchain Fundamentals for Accountants
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with fundamental yet comprehensive knowledge of blockchain technology. Students who wish to explore what blockchain technology’s potential applications are and how they can change the accounting industry are encouraged to take this course. By the end of the course, students are expected to appreciate and reflect on their role as a professional accountant and be ready for the upcoming transition to the new business environment.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:

* ![](file:///C:/Users/ALANW_~1.CUH/AppData/Local/Temp/msohtmlclip1/01/clip_image001.gif)Understand the basic concepts and technologies of blockchain
* Understand and evaluate various blockchain applications and how those would affect accounting and auditing practices.
* ![](file:///C:/Users/ALANW_~1.CUH/AppData/Local/Temp/msohtmlclip1/01/clip_image001.gif)Understand and appreciate how blockchain technology has the potential to impact various aspects of our society, and how it can open the door to many entrepreneurial opportunities

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Regulation and Compliance in the Financial Markets
courses.description: This course is principally designed to provide students with an insight into the financial markets from a regulatory and compliance viewpoint. Amongst others it will include an examination of the role and functions of the various regulators in the banking, insurance and securities industries; the supervision of and compliance by intermediaries; the protection of investors as well as highlighting of current issues that affect the standing of Hong Kong as an international financial centre.

10. Recent market development

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Corporate Insolvency and Restructuring
courses.description: This course will examine the law and regulations relating to corporate restructuring and insolvency in Hong Kong. It will examine issues pertaining to receiverships and liquidations highlighting the role of the professional accountant in such administrations. A portion of the course will focus on transnational insolvency issues.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisites: ACCT3152
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students would be able to have
(1) a better appreciation of the intricacies of corporate restruturing and insolvency
(2) an insight into the highly pragmatic and vexed issues of forensic accounting, cross-border and transnational insolvencies.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course will combine theory with practice in the examination of the issues confronting and of the options available to insolvent and financially distressed companies. Topics covered:
(1) Philosophy of Insolvency Law
(2) Conference on Corporate Rescue
(3) Winding Up Regine in Hong Kong
(4) Antecedent Transactions
(5) Remuneration of Liquidators
(6) Corporate Restructuring
(7) Cross Border Insolvency
(8) Transnational Insolvency
(9) Forensic Accounting
(10) Recent Developments in Insolvency Law

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Chinese Legal Environment for Business
courses.description: This course introduces business students to selected PRC legal and regulatory issues concerning commerce, business management, finance, investment and dispute resolution. A brief discussion of the political and cultural backgrounds of contemporary Chinese business law development is followed by the presentation and examination of a series of topics ranging from the setting up of companies, partnerships and other forms of business operations, transacting on goods and property, employment and labor matters to capital market regulations, intellectual property protections and dispute resolution.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Pre-requisite: ACCT3151.
Not for students who have taken LAWS3320.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
(1) have a basic understanding of Chinese law and legal systems for business strategies and operation;
(2) assess legal issues relating to common business transactions in China; and
(3) further explore and analyze relevant legal subjects on their own.
courses.course_syllabus: This course introduces business students to selected PRC legal and regulatory issues concerning commerce, business management, finance, investment and dispute resolution. A brief discussion of the political and cultural backgrounds of contemporary Chinese business law development is followed by the presentation and examination of a series of topics ranging from the setting up of companies, partnerships and other forms of business operations, transacting on goods and property, employment and labor matters to capital market regulations, intellectual property protections and dispute resolution.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Taxes and Business Strategy
courses.description: The objective of the course is to provide a framework that is useful for thinking about how taxes affect business activities. The focus is the impact of taxes on investment strategies and financing policies. It also considers the tax consequences of compensation alternatives to both the employer and the employee.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisites: ACCT3161
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students will be able to:
1. Acquire an advanced knowledge of taxation in Hong Kong
2. Demonstrate the awareness of current issues and developments in the Hong Kong taxation system
3. Explain and apply the rules and tax cases for determining the source of profits
4. Determine the basis period for profits tax purposes
5. Compute the depreciation allowances for plant and machinery and buildings
6. Apply the tax principles to determine the profits tax liabilities of partnerships and non-residents
7. Understand and apply the loss reliefs
8. Explain the meaning of tax evasion and tax avoidance, various offences and penalties; and apply the anti-avoidance provisions
9. Evaluate the impact of taxation on business decision making and tax planning arrangements
courses.course_syllabus:
The objective of the course is to provide a framework that is useful for thinking about how taxes affect business activities. The focus is the impact of taxes on investment strategies and financing policies. It also considers the tax consequences of compensation alternatives to both the employer and the employee.

Content, highlighting fundamental concepts
1. Locality of profits: case law and practice
2. Profits tax: basis period
3. Profits tax: partnership and loss relief
4. Depreciation allowance: plant and machinery
5. Depreciation allowance: building
6. Taxation of non-residents
7. Tax avoidance, anti-tax avoidance and penalties
8. Tax planning
9. Current issues of Hong Kong Taxation

1. A. Macpherson & G. Laird, “Hong Kong Taxation: Law and Practice”, 2010-11 edition, The Chinese University Press.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: China Taxation
courses.description: This course is designed to familarise students with the China tax system as applicable to individuals, domestic enterprises and foreign invested enterprises. The course examines China’s major state and local tax regimes including individual income tax, enterprise income tax, value-added tax, consumption tax, business tax, land appreciation tax, house property tax, stamp tax and customs duty. It also discusses anti-avoidance measures to counter tax planning (such as transfer pricing) and considers the administrative and professional aspects of tax practice in China.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: ACCT3161
courses.learning_outcomes:
After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

1. Apply the tax principles and legislations to the China tax system and appreciate the interaction of the various taxes
2. Explain and compute the income tax liabilities of individuals and enterprises
3. Explain and compute the effects of value added tax, business tax, consumption tax, land appreciation tax, house property tax and stamp tax for individuals and enterprises
4. Explain and compute the effects of customs duty on the business transactions of individuals and enterprises
5. Apply tax planning techniques for individuals and enterprises and identify the compliance issues for each major tax through a variety of business and personal scenarios and situations
6. Demonstrate an awareness of current issues and developments in the China tax system
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics

1. Overview of the China tax system
2. Income tax on individuals
3. Income tax on enterprises
4. Value added tax, business tax and consumption tax
5. Land appreciation tax and house property tax
6. Stamp tax and customs duty
7. Tax planning and double taxation agreements
8. Transfer pricing rules and anti-avoidance measures
9. Tax administration
10. Current issues in China taxation

Formal teaching evaluation exercise will also be performed at the end of the semester.

1. China Master Tax Guide 2016/17, Deloitte, 13th edition published by Wolters Kluwer CCH
2. CICPA examination books on Taxation (in Simplified Chinese), latest edition

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: International Taxation

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04

courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the issues surrounding the taxation of cross-border activities. The course considers the key concepts of international taxation – the tax jurisdiction of residence and source, international double taxation, relief from double taxation under domestic law and double taxation agreements. It also examines measures to prevent international tax avoidance (such as controlled foreign company rules and transfer pricing), procedural mechanisms by which international tax issues are resolved (e.g. advance pricing agreements), and bilateral administrative issues (e.g. exchange of information and mutual agreement procedure).
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: ACCT3161
courses.learning_outcomes:
After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

1. Identify and assess the tax risks of cross-border activities
2. Understand the policies for taxing international transactions and the principles of company and personal taxation applicable to the taxation of inbound and outbound transactions
3. Understand the relief from double taxation under domestic law and double taxation agreements
4. Identify and apply common types of anti-avoidance provisions designed to counter specified forms of international tax planning
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics

1. Basic principles of international taxation
2. Rules for determining residence and source
3. Taxation of cross border activities
4. Relief from double taxation under domestic law and double taxation agreements
5. International tax avoidance
6. Transfer pricing and thin capitalisation
7. Controlled foreign corporation rules
8. Exchange of information and mutual agreement procedure
9. Current issues in international taxation

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Corporate Governance
courses.description: This course introduces and analyses important corporate governance issues and their causes and consequences, with an emphasis of emerging markets and transitional economies. Topics include the effects of institutional factors on corporate governance, corporate ownership structures and managerial incentives, corporate governance issues of different organizational forms, various corporate governance mechanisms adopted for enhancing corporate governance, and the effects of corporate governance in accounting. Students seeking a career in accounting, finance, commercial law and management should find this course interesting and relevant.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: ACCT2121
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to
(1) understand the important institutional and human factors in business operations that are often not considered in traditional courses
(2) acquire the concept on the different governance issues and practices in these markets.
courses.course_syllabus: The course covers important corporate governance issues and their resolutions through lectures, case studies, and discussion of contemporary research and public opinions. Topics covered in this course include the importance of institutional factors (such as public governance and legal protection) in corporate governance, corporate ownership structures and managerial incentives, corporate governance issues of family firms and state owned enterprises, corporate governance mechanisms (boards of directors and executivee compensation), corporate transparency and corporate accounting reporting.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are welcomed to provide comments and feedback to the instructor via email, appointment and the CTE exercise.
courses.required_readings: Kenneth Kim and John Nofsinger, 2004, Corporate Governance, (Prentice Hall), KN here after.
courses.recommended_readings: It is expected that you will be an aggressive reader of business publications (Chinee or English), including Xin Pao, The New Fortune, Cai Jin, The 21st Century Economic Report, The Asian Wall Street Journal, The South China Morning Post, The Economists, Business Week, and so forth. Please look for opportunities to apply class materials to your reading of the business press and volunteer your observations in class.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: ESG and Sustainability Accounting
courses.description: This course helps students obtain a broad and critical understanding of how accountants can contribute to an organisation’s value creation through ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) initiatives. The course introduces different theories and perspectives that explain the growing importance of ESG and focusses on how such ESG issues are measured, reported and valued by capital market participants. The course compares major ESG reporting frameworks and their applications in the real world. The course also explores how ESG issues can be integrated into traditional accounting disciplines such as management and cost accounting, internal controls, performance measurement and assurance.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: ACCT3121
courses.course_syllabus:
1. **An introduction of ESG**
2. **Management accounting and control (MAC) for sustainability**
3. **Measuring and rating CSR/ESG**
4. **Reporting standards of ESG practices and sustainability issues**
5. **Special accounting topics on ESG**
courses.feedback_evaluation: CTE will be done at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings:

Reading material including cases will be assigned in advance via Blackboard.

* Del Baldo et al. 2020, Accounting, accountability and society. Springer
* Herriott. 2016. Metrics for sustainable business. Routledge New York and London
* Laine et al. 2022. Sustainability accounting and accountability (3rd edition). Routledge New York and London.
* Rimmel. 2021. Accounting for sustainability. Routledge New York and London.
* Hill. 2020. Environmental, social, and governance (ESG) investing. Academic Press

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Applied Accounting and Financial Strategies
courses.description: This course introduces cutting-edge accounting and market based analytical techniques for guiding managerial decision making. The course will examine how financial statement and market data are used for estimating value creation (or destruction) in important managerial decisions, including working capital management, long-term financing, debt-equity choices, payout policies, corporate governance, financial and operational restructuring, and mergers and acquisitions. Students pursuing a career in accounting, auditing, financial analysis, corporate finance, investment banking, or management consulting will find this course highly relevant.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisites: ACCT2121 and FINA2010
courses.course_syllabus: This course introduces cutting-edge theories and analytical techniques for guiding corporate accounting and financial decision making. These decisions include long-term financing, debt-equity choices, payout policies, mergers and acquisitions, corporate transparency, and corporate governance. Students pursuing a career in accouning, auditing, financial analysis, corporate finance, investment banking, or management consulting will find this course highly relevant.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are welcomed to provide comments and feedback to the instructor via email, appointment and the CTE exercise.
courses.required_readings: Corporate Finance by Scott Smart, William Megginson, and Lawrence Gitman ("Smart" here after), South-Western, 2007.
courses.recommended_readings: It is expected that you will be an aggressive reader of business publications (Chinese or English), including Xin Pao, The New Fortune, Cai Jin, The 21st Century Economic Report, The Asian Wall Street Journal, The South China Morning Post, The Economists, Business Week, and so forth. Please look for opportunities to apply class material to your reading of the business press and volunteer your observations in class.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Reporting Issues in Financial Services Industry
courses.description: Financial services industry a specialised sector. This course highlights the specialised financial reporting considerations applicable to various types of entities in the financial services industry sectors such as banking and securities, insurance and asset wealth management (including fund and private equity).
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: ACCT3112
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Topics:**

1. Accounting for more complex financial instruments such as derivatives and embedded derivatives applying HKFRS 9 *Financial Instruments*
2. Accounting for risk management strategies using cash flow hedge and fair value hedge
3. Credit review process for a corporate bank, including common credit products, the credit cycle, governance and risk mitigation methods
4. Introduction of the role of asset managers and various fund types such as mutual funds, hedge funds, unit trusts, pension funds and private equities
5. Financial reporting issues relating to various funds and asset managers
6. Different forms of insurance arrangements
7. Different measurement models in HKFRS 17 *Insurance Contracts* in the preparation of the insurer’s financial statements
8. Risk disclosure in the financial statements of a financial institution
9. Other regulatory reporting requirements in the financial services sector
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are welcomed to send their comments/feedback to the course instructor. The channels include: (1) e-mails to the instructor; (2) appointment with the instructor; and (3) formal CTE exercise.

M. Hudson, Funds: Private Equity, Hedge and all Core Structures, Wiley, 2014.
