courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Professional Accounting Internship
courses.description:
This course provides :
a. Provide real life working experience in local and/or international contexts;b. Develop an in-depth and practical understanding of business operations and the professional environment by applying the theoretical knowledge, concepts and practical skills of accounting and business learnt in the formal curriculum;c. Sharpen students' skills in effective communication, individual and team work, time management, data analysis and reporting; and
d. Develop students' ability to explore different ways and knowledge to solve real-life problem(s) during the internship period.

Key elements of the course:
1. Students can take the course over each semester, and also in summer term; 2. Minimum requirement of internship hours is 150 hours; 3. Eligibility: Accounting/Finance-related internship offered by employers including HKICPA approved firms, ACCA approved firms, Government entities, Regulators, Banks and Others (subject to approval);4. Students need to ask their internship supervisors to fill out a form; and
5. Students need to write a report for the internship.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Attitude: Develop an attitude of discovery/innovation/creativity, as demonstrated by students possessing a strong sense of curiosity,asking questions actively, challenging assumptions or engaging in inquiry together with teachers.

2: Ability: Develop the ability/skill needed to discover/innovate/create, as demonstrated by students possessing critical thinking skillsto assess ideas, acquiring research skills, synthesizing knowledge across disciplines or applying academic knowledge toreal-life problems.

3: Accomplishments: Demonstrate accomplishment of discovery/innovation/creativity through producing /constructing creative works/newartefacts, effective solutions to real-life problems or new processes.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Advanced Financial Accounting and Reporting
courses.description: This course deals with advanced aspects of financial accounting. Topics covered include the financial reporting environment in Hong Kong, fair value accounting, intangible assets, contingent liabilities, deferred income taxes, accounting for post-retirement benefits, equity and cost methods of accounting for long-term investments, business combinations (purchase and pooling), consolidation of parent/subsidiary financial statements, and interpretation of financial statements. Students will be required to critically evaluate various accounting valuation, reporting and disclosure issues.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Accountancy
courses.course_syllabus:
- Share-based Payment
- Accounting for Taxes on Income
- Accounting for the Effects of Change in Foreign Exchange Rates
- Derivatives and Hedge Accounting Part I
- Derivatives and Hedge Accounting Part II
- Group Reporting I: Concept
- Group Reporting II: Acquisition Method under IFRS 3
- Group Reporting III: Accounting for Business Combination and Non-controlling
- Interest in Post-acquisition Period under IFRS 3
- Group Reporting IV: Consolidation under IFRS 10 Part I
- Group Reporting IV: Consolidation under IFRS 10 Part II
- Group Reporting V: Equity Accounting under IAS 28
- Special Issues on Consolidation: Deferred Tax
- Effects on Consolidation, Step Acquisitions
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: P. Tan, L.C. Yeoung, and K.E. Wen, Advanced Financial Accounting: An IFRS Approach, 4th Edition, McGraw Hill.
courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher

courses.description: This course provides a graduate-level overview of the principles and concepts that underlie corporate financial reporting and the economic consequences of accounting choices. The course focus is on developing the skills required to interpret the information contained in financial statements and its use in decision-making rather than on the skills required to prepare financial statements. Topics include the use of accounting information in evaluating firm performance, and corporate reporting policies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Executive Master of Professional Accountancy; or MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme; or MSc Finance
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:
a) Understand the conceptual underpinnings of financial accounting
b) Understand how the financial reports are prepared
c) Understand how to interpret and use accounting information
d) Carry out forecasting and valuation analysis using financial accounting information
courses.course_syllabus:
Lecture 1: Overview of Financial Statements
Lecture 2: Revenue Confirmation
Lecture 3: Inventory
Lecture 4: Long-term Assets
Lecture 5: Intangible Assets
Lecture 6: Income Tax
Lecture 7: Intercompany Investment
Lecture 8: Hedge Trading
Lecture 9: Securitization
Lecture 10: Lease
Lecture 11: Pension
Lecture 12: Equity and Equity incentives
Lecture 13: Non-main business items and earnings per share
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: Lecture notes

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Financial and Managerial Accounting

meetings.instructor:
Professor ZHOU Xiaolu, 
Professor ZHU Chunmei

Professor ZHOU Xiaolu, 
Professor ZHU Chunmei

courses.description: The overall goal of this course is to provide students with the knowledge to understand, evaluate, and act on financial and non-financial information used in managing contemporary organizations. It considers two distinct perspectives of users of accounting information: external and internal users. In particular, the course introduces basic concepts of financial and managerial accounting and presents commonly-used analytical tools and techniques to help with decision-making. Such decisions cover a broad range of user objectives such as investing, lending, assessing competitiveness, pricing of products, costing, inventory management, performance measurement, etc.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Management
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students are expected to:
- differentiate between assessing a company from the outside and measuring performance from an internal perspective
- analyze and critically judge the financial and non-financial performance of an enterprise using financial statements
- understand modern concepts of internal resource management, revenue generation, cost behavior, and ultimately performance evaluation through profitability and non-financial metrics
courses.course_syllabus:
• Introduction to the accrual concept; accrual and cash accounting
• Basic financial statements and financial ratios
• Income statement; revenue recognition, expenses, profits; the matching principle
• Balance sheet; assets, liabilities, and shareholders’ equity; the accounting equation
• Cash flow statement; operating, investing, and financing activities
• Introduction to cost concepts; allocating costs and activity-based costing, the cost-volume-profit (CVP) relationship
• Planning and analyzing performance: budgeting, standard costing and variance analysis
• Assessing performance in the context of strategy; People-Service-Profit and the Balanced Scorecard
• Decentralization, transfer pricing, and multinational considerations
• Performance evaluation, incentives and behavioral issues
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: The course is intended to provide a quick summary of the gist of two otherwise full courses in accounting. Thus, its structure does not follow any standard textbook. As a result, there is no required textbook for the course.
courses.recommended_readings:
“Financial and Managerial Accounting for MBAs,” by Peter Easton, Robert Halsey, Mary Lea McAnally, Al Hartgraves, Dale Morse Wayne Morse
“Financial Accounting”
“Management/Managerial Accounting”

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Cost and Management Accounting
courses.description: This course introduces the students to the basic concepts, techniques and application of cost and management accounting. Topics include cost concepts, cost behaviour, costing systems, cost determination and allocation, standard costing and variance analysis, relevant costs, and budgetary planning and performance evaluation. Methods and techniques of cost management in the service sector and in the advanced manufacturing environment are discussed. Accounting implications for management planning, control, and decision-making will be emphasized. Throughout this course, students will be expected to actively participate in class seminars case discussions.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Accountancy
courses.course_syllabus:
• Introduction of management accounting
• Basic cost concept
• CVP analysis
• Cost behavior
• Using costs for decision making
• make-or-buy
• add/drop product
• pricing
• product-mix decision
• machine replacement
• Job order costing
• Process costing
• Activity-based costing
• Measuring and managing customer relationships
• Lean manufacturing
• Facility layout systems
• Inventory costs and processing time
• Costs of nonconformance and quality issues
• Just-in-time manufacturing
• Life-cycle costs, target costing and environment costing
• The Balanced Scorecard and strategy map
• Budgeting and control (1)
• Budgeting and control (2)
• Financial control
• Responsibility centers and evaluating unit performance
• Transfer pricing
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: To be assigned by course teacher
courses.recommended_readings:
Reference Books:
1. Anthony A. Atkinson, Robert S. Kaplan, Ella Mae Matsumura and S. Mark Young, “Management Accounting – Information for Decision Making and Strategy Execution”, 6th Edition. Pearson Education, Inc.
2. Srikant M. Datar and Madhav Rajan, “Horngren’s Cost Accounting – A Managerial Emphasis”, 16th Edition. Pearson Education, Inc.
3. Brian Clarke, Paul Collier, Rahat Munir, Gary R Oliver, Peter Robinson, Natasja Steenkamp and Ofer Zwikael; “Strategic Management Accounting”, 2nd Edition, CPA Australia.
4. Strategic Business Leader (SBL); Study Text of ACCA; Kaplan Publishing.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Auditing and Professional Practice
courses.description: This course will provide an examination of the economic theory of auditing, the role and responsibilities of auditors, the concepts and techniques employed by auditors, and auditing procedures for balance sheet and profit and loss items. Other topics include the public accounting profession, internal control, audit planning, audit reports and professional ethics. Topics of current interest available in the literature will also be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Accountancy
courses.course_syllabus:
• Overview of Auditing
• Auditing Standards Setting Process
• Audit Reports
• Professional Ethics
• Legal Liability
• Audit Responsibility and Objectives
• Audit Evidence
• Audit Planning and Analytical Procedures
• Materiality and Risk
• Internal Control and Control Risk
• Overall Audit Plan and Audit Program
• Sales and Collection Cycle – Test of Control
• Audit Sampling for Test of Control
• Sales and Collection Cycle – Accounts Receivable
• Acquisition and Payment Cycle
• Completing the Audit
• Legal liability
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: Arens, Elder and Beasley, Auditing and Assurance Services - An Integrated Approach, 16th Edition, Prentice-Hall International, 2016. (AEB) Global Edition.
courses.recommended_readings: Members’ Handbook, Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants (www.hkicpa.org.hk)

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Introductory Accounting Data Analytics
courses.description: This course is designed to prepare students with the necessary tools and skills they need to successfully perform data analytics. The course requires students to have basic financial and managerial accounting knowledge. Students will learn about using data analytics to ask and answer accounting and business questions, preparing data for analysis, performing different types of data analysis using data analysis tools such as Excel and Tableau. Finally, students will learn how to communicate the analysis results effectively using different types of visualizations. Hands-on computer laboratory sessions will form an integral part of this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Accountancy
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
1. use data analytics to ask and answer accounting and business questions
2. perform extract, transform and load (ETL) procedures for data preparation and cleaning
3. perform descriptive, diagnostic, predictive and prescriptive analysis related to financial reporting, management accounting, auditing and financial statements analysis independently
4. communicate the analysis results effectively using appropriate visualizations

1 Analytics Mindset
AMPS Model
- A for Ask the Question
- M for Master the Data
- P for Perform the Analysis
- S for Share the Story

Richardson ch. 1

2 Data, Data Analytics and Accounting
- ERP system
- What is big data?
- Accounting and non-accounting data sources

References:
Richardson ch. 2

3 Types of Data
- Numerical vs Categorical Data
- Data Dictionaries
- Structured vs. Unstructured Data

References:
Richardson ch. 3

4 Preparing Data for Analysis
- Data availability
- Obtaining External and Internal Data
- ETL (Extract, Transform and Load) introduction
- Data modeling and relational database

References:
Richardson ch. 4

5 Types and Tools of Data Analysis
- Descriptive Analysis
- Diagnostic Analysis
- Predictive Analysis
- Prescriptive Analysis
- Introduction to Data Analysis Tools (such as Excel and Tableau)

References:
Richardson ch. 5

6 Perform Different Types of Analysis related to
- Financial reporting (e.g. aging analysis)
- Management reporting (e.g. balanced score card dashboard)
- Auditing (e.g. Benford’s Law, fuzzy matching)
- Financial statement analysis (e.g. XBRL)

References:
Richardson ch. 6 to 9

7 Visualizations and Communicating Results

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Business and Company Law
courses.description: This course introduces students to the institutions, doctrine and methodology of the law in the business and corporation contents. After a discussion of the legal system of Hong Kong SAR, the first part of the course examines selected subjects in contract, tort of negligence, employment, and sales of goods. The second part of the course will focus on company law, such as formation of companies, the effects of incorporations, the division of powers and obligations among various organs of the company, its relationship with outsiders, financing and dividend issues, and options available to companies in financial difficulties.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Accountancy
courses.learning_outcomes: Students can know the important rules of business law and company law at the end of the course. These rules concern how the courts deal with business-related disputes and issues relating to the running of companies in the real life. As many of the rules are designed to protect consumers and shareholders, students can in particular know more about consumers’ rights and shareholders’ rights. In addition, they can also learn more analytical skills and writing skills which can help them to apply the rules to do their assessments.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. The legal system of the Hong Kong SAR
• The Basic Law, legislation (including the anti-bribery law and laws against money laundering), common law, equity and the court system
2. Contract law
• Formation of contracts (offer, acceptance, intention to create legal relations, consideration and formality), contract terms and exemption clauses, vitiating factors (misrepresentation, undue influence, illegality and unconscionable contracts), discharge of contracts (performance, agreement and frustration) and the remedies for breach of contract (damages, rescission, injunction and specific performance)
3. Torts law
• Negligence
4. Company law
• Business organizations and incorporation, the external regulatory bodies, the constitution of a company, the raising of capital and the maintenance of share capital, the management of a company, the dissolution of a company and solutions for companies having financial difficulties
5. Employment and agency laws
• Employees / independent contractors and the rights of employees, and agency law principles
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings:
1. D.K. Srivastava, ed., Business Law in Hong Kong (Hong Kong: Sweet & Maxwell Asia, 6th ed., 2020)
2. Vanessa Stott, Hong Kong Company Law (Hong Kong: Person Education Asia Limited, 15th ed., 2020)
courses.recommended_readings: Stefan HC Lo and Charles Qu, Law of Companies in Hong Kong (Hong Kong: Sweet & Maxwell, 3rd ed., 2018)

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Taxation and Tax Planning
courses.description: This course covers the basic elements and statutes of Hong Kong taxation system, including salaries tax, property tax, profits tax, personal assessment, depreciation allowances, and tax administration. After this basic knowledge, the course will introduce advanced concepts of tax planning, problem solving with practical examples and the inter-relationships between different types of taxes. Local tax cases will be discussed extensively.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Accountancy
courses.course_syllabus:
• Hong Kong tax system and property tax
• Salaries tax – Scope and source
• Salaries tax – Assessable income and net assessable income
• Salaries tax – NAI, net chargeable income and assessment
• Profits tax – Scope and source
• Profits tax – Computation of assessable profits
• Profits tax – Computation of APs and depreciation allowance
• Profits tax – DA, partnership and loss relief
• Personal assessment and tax administration
• Stamp duty
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings:
1. Patrick Kin-wai Ho & Kelvin Po-lung Mak, Hong Kong Taxation and Tax Planning, 19th edition, Pilot Publishing Co Ltd
2. Inland Revenue Ordinance, Chapter 112, The Government Printer
3. Inland Revenue Rules, Chapter 112A, The Government Printer
4. Stamp Duty Ordinance, Chapter 117, The Government Printer
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Hong Kong Tax Cases, The Government Printer
2. Inland Revenue Board of Review Decisions, The Government Printer
3. Departmental Interpretation & Practice Notes, Inland Revenue Department
4. Stamp Office Interpretation & Practice Notes, Inland Revenue Department
5. A. Macpherson Lau & M. Olesnicky, Hong Kong Taxation: Law and Practice, 2018-19 edition, The Chinese University Press

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Accounting
courses.description: The primary objective of the course is to provide students with a solid conceptual and practical understanding of financial accounting. Emphasis is placed on understanding the content and principles underlying financial statements. From this a sound foundation is built on which students can make more informed business judgments and decisions.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in EMBA (Chinese)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:
a) Distinguish among financial vs managerial vs tax accounting
b) Identify the economic events that are to be included in the financial reports
c) Apply the classification criteria for revenues, expenses, assets, liabilities, and equity accounting
d) Distinguish between cash and accrual accounting
e) Prepare and analyze financial statements
f) Explain cost relations and types and apply cost-volume-profit (CVP) analysis
g) Apply relevant cost analysis
h) Describe the roles of budgeting, standard costing, and variance analysis
i) Acknowledge and demonstrate limitations of purely accounting-based decision making

courses.description: The primary objective of the course is to provide students with a solid conceptual and practical understanding of financial and managerial accounting. Emphasis is placed on understanding the concepts and principles underlying financial statements and cost, volume and profit analysis. From this a sound foundation is built on which students can make more informed business judgments and decisions.

By completing this course, students will be able to:
1. Distinguish clearly among financial vs managerial vs tax accounting
2. Identify the economic events that are to be included in the financial reports
3. Demonstrate and apply the classification criteria for revenues, expenses, assets, liabilities, and equity accounting
4. Highlight the important distinction between cash and accrual accounting
5. Prepare and analyze financial statements
6. Explain cost relations and types and apply cost-volume-profit (CVP) analysis

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Fundamental Accounting – Financial Statement Analysis
courses.description: The objective of this course is to provide an in-depth analysis of the requirement and practice of financial reporting and financial disclosure in mainland China and listed Chinese companies, including A-share, B-share, and H-share firms. The course consists of four parts: 1) the legal and regulatory framework; 2) the reporting and disclosure process; 3) issues in analysing IPO prospectus; and 4) issues in analysing annual/interim reports. The course will be a mix of lectures, class discussion, and cases.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA in Finance (40087); or MBA in Finance (40324)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students will:
- be able to read financial statements
- understand the principles of drafting financial statements
- be able to understand how external environment and internal factors influence the value relevance of accounting information of enterprises
- be able to apply economic intuition and dynamic method to analyse the effect of enterprise management, investment and financing strategies on accounting information
courses.course_syllabus:
This course will fully describe the basic conceptual framework and analytical theoretical system of financial reporting. The focus of course content design is to help students build an effective theoretical framework for financial analysis based on the understanding of accounting concepts. We must not only understand the meaning of accounting concepts within the framework of the standards, but also have a deep understanding of the impact of internal corporate governance arrangements and the external institutional environment on accounting information. In the teaching process, we will not ignore the fraud in the company's financial reporting practice, and summarize the frequently used financial fraud sections of financial reporting entities to improve the effectiveness of financial analysis. The course will also combine financial analysis with alternative data analysis, and introduce the application of emerging technologies in the field of financial analysis, to help students re-examine financial analysis with a broader perspective.

本科目將全⾯的講述財務報告的基本概念框架及分析理論體系。科目內容設計的重點在於幫助學⽣在理解會計概念的基礎之上，構建⾏之有效的財務分析理論框架。我們不僅要理解準則框架內會計概念的意義， ⽽且，要深入理解內部公司治理安排以及外部制度環境對會計信息的影響。我們在教學過程中也不會忽略公司財務報告實踐中的舞弊⾏為，總結財務報告實體常⽤的財務舞弊⼿段， 以提⾼財務分析的有效性。科目也會把財務分析與另類數據分析相結合， 並介紹新興技術在財務分析領域的應⽤， 幫助學⽣⽤⼀個更廣的視角重新審視財務分析。

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Contemporary Management Accounting
courses.description: This course examines the use of contemporary accounting systems for cost measurement, control, performance evaluation, and as a source of sustainable competitive advantage. The course begins with discussion of cost concepts and traditional accounting control and costing systems and then proceeds to examination of contemporary accounting systems including activity-based systems for product pricing, cost control and customer profitability management, and EVA and Balanced Scorecard systems for strategic control and performance evaluation. Practical exposure to the use of these systems in decision-making and the issues involved in their design and implementation are provided through the use of case analysis, current research and student projects. Prerequisite: ACCT5111
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Executive Master of Professional Accountancy;Pre-requisite: ACCT5111
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to use accounting information in decision analysis and control, including cost analysis and control, profit planning, budgeting, variance analysis, responsibility accounting, and incentive system design and implementation.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Management accounting concept
• Basic cost concept
• Cost-Volume-Profit analysis
• Cost function

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Company Law and Security Law of China
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the legal system of China’s capital market. Topics covered include: the corporate governance of companies, the process of companies going public, the information disclosure requirement of listed companies, and security trading regulations in China.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA in Finance (40087); or MBA in Finance (40324)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students will:
- be familiar with existing Chinese rules and practices
- be able to identify and compare different conceptions of and approaches to law to bring home systemic problems China has encountered in its modernization efforts
- be familiar with the economic, political and historical backgrounds of company law as well as main provisions of PRC company legislation
- be able to analyse cases concerning various company law issues that have been litigated
- have thorough understanding of problems of securities markets and investor protection as well as theories dealing with those problems
- be familiar with legal issues related to the issuance and transactions of securities as well as liabilities of different actors
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Improvement of Company Law and Corporate Governance
2. Securities Market Development and Corporate Governance
3. Hostile Mergers and Reverse Takeovers
4. Independent Directors and Corporate Governance
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: To be assigned by course teacher
courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Accounting Field Study
courses.description: The course is designed to expose students to a wide spectrum of global accounting related issues in a non-local business environment. Students will take a week-long residential programme in various countries or regions. Course learning activities include lectures at universities, case projects, seminars and discussions with local accounting professionals and/or government officials, and site visits to enterprises.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Accountancy
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completion of this course, students are expected to be able to:
1. understand accounting practice in different countries and regions
2. understand business models of different enterprises and the supporting role of accounting
3. communicate effectively and efficiently in a professional way
courses.course_syllabus:
1: Classroom lectures
Students will take classroom lectures at universities in the visiting countries and regions. The purpose of classroom lectures is to help students understand local accounting practice.

2: Group case project
Students will be required to study business models of the enterprises they will visit and present their findings to the class. The purpose of the group case project is to help students better understand the enterprises and relevant industries, and learn more about the supporting role of accounting from the visits.

3: Visits to enterprises
Visits to enterprises will be arranged. Through these visits, students have chances to know about operating process and accounting practice of real-world enterprises. They also have chances to talk to management of those enterprises to understand how accounting helps enterprises implement their business models.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
2. Students are warmly welcomed to provide comments/feedback on the course by sending e-mails to the course instructor and/or making appointments with the course instructor.
courses.required_readings: Students will be required to study business models of the enterprises before the firm visit and present their findings to the class.
courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Field Study for Accounting Managers
courses.description: The course is designed to expose students to a wide spectrum of global accounting related issues in a non-local business environment. Students will take at least a week-long residential programme in various countries or regions. Course learning activities include lectures and/or seminars at universities, discussions with local accounting professionals and/or government officials, and site visits to enterprises.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Executive Master of Professional Accountancy
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completion of this course, students are expected to be able to:
(1) understand accounting practice in different countries and regions
(2) understand business models of different enterprises and the supporting role of accounting
(3) communicate effectively in a professional way
courses.course_syllabus:
- Professional seminars in accounting and finance
- Site visits to enterprises
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students will be asked to complete an evaluation form on the study trip for improvement.
Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: No required readings

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Python Essentials for Accounting Analytics
courses.description: This course introduces basic Python programming techniques for accounting data analytics. It guides students through Python programming logic, data processing, and graphical visualization in an accounting and finance context. The focus is on Python's fundamental aspects, including syntax, control structures, and handling complex, unstructured data in practical situations. Students will learn effective data handling with Python to support decision-making and business analysis.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Accountancy
courses.learning_outcomes:
The objectives of the course are to:

* Master fundamental Python programming logic
* Understand Python's applications in accounting and finance
* Perform data processing and cleaning with Python
* Visualize financial data effectively
* Support decision making through Python programming
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics

1. Introduction to Python applications in accounting

2. Overview of Python programming

3. Basic Python syntax and control structures

4. Functions and data handling

5. Data visualization and forecast with Python

6. Company Information environment and unstructured data analysis

7. Crowd-based information platform and corporate decision-making

8. Frontiers in data analytics and AI development
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: There is no textbook required. The background readings and academic papers would be provided prior to the class.
courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Financial Accounting Theory
courses.description: This course establishes a framework for evaluating accounting choices and categorizing the strength of authority for particular accounting treatments. This is accomplished by exposing the students to empirical accounting research and by creating an awareness of the endogenous factors affecting accounting decisions. Major themes are the integration of cash flow and accrual based measures of income from a theoretical perspective and the synthesis of accounting choice questions based on the asset valuation versus income measurement dichotomy. The end result will be a deeper understanding of both the structure and the process of accounting policy-making.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Accountancy
courses.course_syllabus:
• Introduction, Accounting and the Capital Market
• Accounting Theoretical Framework
• Decision Usefulness
• Efficient Capital Market & Information Perspective
• Measurement Approach
• Measurement Approach: Fair Value Accounting
• Other Applications of the Measurement Approach and Economic Consequences
• Positive Accounting Theory and Earnings Management
• Game Theory
• Accounting and Compensation
• Standard Setting, Nonfinancial Disclosure and Review, International convergence
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: To be assigned by course teacher
courses.recommended_readings: William R. Scott, Financial Accounting Theory, Latest (7th or above) Edition. Pearson.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Business Valuation and Analysis
courses.description: This course introduces a framework for business valuation analysis using corporate disclosure and financial statement data. The framework identifies four key components of valuation: business strategy analysis, accounting analysis, financial analysis, and prospective analysis. Employing a case methodology, applications of this framework in a variety of decision-making contexts including securities analysis, credit analysis, and merger and acquisition decisions are examined.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Accountancy; or Executive Master of Professional Accountancy; or MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme; or MBA in Finance
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students should be able to:
a) Develop a comprehensive framework for business analysis and valuation by identifying and utilizing value relevant information provided in the financial statements
b) Analyze accounting policies, evaluate earnings quality and make necessary adjustments to financial statements
c) Apply appropriate financial tools to perform critical analysis on firm’s profitability, liquidity, solvency and asset utilization
d) Formulate sound financial decisions under context-specific settings by incorporating the strategic, accounting and financing activities of a business entity into the performance/valuation analysis
e) Show the competency in writing a thorough, credible and professional financial statement analysis report
courses.course_syllabus:
• Overview of Financial Statement Analysis and Information Collection
• Understanding the Business
• Accounting Analysis
• Financial Ratio Analysis
• Cash Flow Analysis
• Structured Forecasting
• Forecasting Details
• The Cost of Capital
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: Equity Valuation & Analysis, 4th Edition by Russell Lundholm and Richard Sloan, 2017
courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Comparative Financial Reporting
courses.description: This course examines the evolution of accounting under different political and economic systems and explores current theory and research on the impact of local institutional features on financial reporting and disclosure practices. In so doing, it provides students with a conceptual framework for analyzing the economic causes and consequences of differences in reporting and disclosure practices and their impact on international commerce, finance, and investment. The course includes discussion of recent and proposed changes in reporting standards with a focus on the local and Mainland reporting environment.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Accountancy; or Executive Master of Professional Accountancy; or MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students should be able to:
- Understand the major differences among IFRS, US GAAP and China Accounting Standards, and the progress in their convergences.
- Understand the most recent accounting development in the world and be familiar with important new accounting standards.
- Understand the economic consequences of accounting policies and choices from the perspectives of investors, managers, and government regulators.
- Improve the ability of making good judgment to complex business transactions.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topic 1: Inventory
Topic 2: PPE
Topic 3: M&A and Goodwill
Topic 4: Lease
Topic 5: Consolidation
Topic 6: Revenue Recognition

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Comprehensive Budget Management
courses.description: The course introduces to students a systematic and scientific budget management system. Through case studies, students can understand how to prepare a reasonable budget, how to promote communication between enterprise and departments, how to clear and quantify the company's business objectives, how to develop and continuously adjust the business plan and use the budget to regulate the management of the company, and finally how the financial budget becomes a comprehensive budget that can guarantee the success of the company.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Executive Master of Professional Accountancy
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completion of this course, students are expected to be able to:
(1) understand the importance of a comprehensive budget for a company to achieve its strategic goals
(2) understand the key points of an efficient and comprehensive budget management system
(3) understand the building ideas for a company's budget management system
(4) understand the processes, tools and methods of budgeting
(5) master an effective way to monitor and evaluate business operations through budget management
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics include:
- budget management
- budget, strategy and goals
- process and method of budget preparation
- effective implementation and control of the overall budget
- comprehensive budget tracking and analysis
- comprehensive budget assessment
- promotion strategy and function positioning of budget management
- common analysis of the difficulty of budget management

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Management Control Systems
courses.description: Designed properly, management control systems serve to influence and structure employee behavior in ways that increase the likelihood that organizational objectives are achieved or exceeded. This course provides an advanced-level examination of the alternative control mechanisms available to organizations, theories underlying their use, and their intended and often unintended effects on behavior. Particular attention is directed to the critical decisions underlying the design of effective accounting based control systems including choice of responsibility structure, performance measures, performance standards, and incentive systems, and to emerging issues in corporate governance.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Accountancy; or Executive Master of Professional Accountancy
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:
a) Be equipped with basic concepts of management control systems
b) Understand the design and implementation of various control structures and tools using management accounting
courses.course_syllabus:

• Management Control Types, Tightness, Costs, and Design
• Financial Responsibility Centers and Transfer Pricing
• Planning and Budgeting
• Incentive Compensation Systems
• Financial Performance Measures
• Combination of Measures and Myopia Problem
• Financial Results Control and Uncontrollable Factors
• Controllers and Auditors
• Strategy and Adaptation Costs
• Ethical Issues in Management Control Systems
• Control in Nonprofits

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Advances in Strategic Management Accounting
courses.description: This is an advanced course in management accounting examining the role of management accounting systems in strategy formation and implementation and as a potential source of sustainable competitive advantage. The course blends current research with practical exposure to the issues involved in the design and implementation of these systems. Topics include cost of capacity, activity-based management systems for operational and strategic control and contemporary approaches to performance coordination and evaluation in a decentralized environment.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Accountancy; or Executive Master of Professional Accountancy
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:
a) Understand how organizations implement business strategies successfully with effective management control systems
b) Understand how organizations employ strategic cost management tools to develop sustainable competitive advantages

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Assurance Services and Information Technology
courses.description: This course examines Hong Kong legal environment and discusses how it will affect audit risk, audit planning, internal controls, analytical procedures, and substantive tests. Building on this foundation, this course then focuses on information technology and examines its impacts on financial reporting systems. Specifically, we emphasize on how auditors can leverage information technology and use Computer-Assisted Audit Tools and Techniques (CAAT) to attest clients’ financial statements.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For student in Master of Accountancy;Prerequisite: ACCT5130
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to:
1. Understand Hong Kong legal environment and how it affects auditing and assurance services
2. Be familiar with internal control framework, audit risk model, and auditing planning
3. Understand how audit judgments affect evidence accumulation
4. Be familiar with statistical sampling and non-statistical sampling approaches in auditing
5. Understand how to document clients’ business processes
6. Comprehend how to evaluate clients’ internal controls over financial reporting
7. Realize the information security issues related to clients’ accounting systems
8. Be familiar with Computer-Assisted Audit Tools and Techniques (CAAT) and Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP)
9. Understand the relationship between application controls and substantive tests
10. Realize auditors’ responsibilities over client’s fraudulent activities
courses.course_syllabus:
• Hong Kong legal environment and its effects on auditing and professional services
• COSO internal controls framework, audit risk, and auditing planning
• Audit judgment and audit evidence accumulation
• Statistical sampling and non-statistical sampling approaches in auditing
• Business processes and financial reporting systems
• Accounting information systems
• Information security
• CAAT and ERP
• Application controls and substantive testing
• Auditors’ responsibilities over client’s fraudulent activities

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Fraud Examination and Forensic Investigation
courses.description: Fraud examination and forensic investigation is a growing area of practice in which the knowledge, skills and abilities of advanced accounting are combined with investigative expertise and applied to legal problems. This course covers the important underpinnings as well as the substance of forensic investigation of fraudulent activities such as financial statement frauds, cybercrime activities, corruption and money laundering schemes. The course also explores how analytics tools help forensic accountants to maximise auditing and analytic capabilities.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Accountancy;Pre-requisite: ACCT5130
courses.learning_outcomes:
The objectives of the course are to:
1. equip students with an understanding of the role of forensic accountants (or fraud examiners);
2. let students understand how a forensic accountant can assist top management in preventing, detecting and correcting frauds; and
3. strengthen students’ awareness of how technology helps respond to fraud risks from a technical and practical perspective.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Fraud Principles and Fraud Risk Assessment
• Fraudulent Financial Reporting
• Employee Fraud, including Misappropriation of Assets
• Indirect Methods of Reconstructing Income
• Money Laundering and Transnational Financial Flows
• Evidence-based Fraud Examination
• Interviewing and Interrogation
• Using Information Technology for Fraud Examination and Financial Forensics
• Computer Crimes and Cyber Forensics
• Antifraud and Compliance Efforts: Ethics, Prevention and Deterrence

2. Kranacher and Riley. Forensic Accounting and Fraud Examination, Wiley, 2nd Edition, 2019.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Accounting Information Systems and Internal Control
courses.description: This course consists of two related areas. This first part analyzes information systems from a management control perspective, emphasizing organization environment, technology, decision models and performance evaluation as determinants of information processing requirements; using cases and design projects to explore the management of information processing systems, major functional applications and impacts of information technology on individuals and society. The second part introduces the systems, procedures, and processes management employed to control operating activities, information reporting systems, and compliance with applicable laws, rules and regulations. Topics include design and evaluation perspectives of control environment, risk assessment, control activities, information and communication and monitoring.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Executive Master of Professional Accountancy; or Master of Accountancy
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:
(1) Understand the relationship between information systems, internal control and enterprise risk management.
(2) Recognize the relationship between general control, application control, and information system construction in contemporary information accounting systems.
(3) Understand the theory and structure of relational databases. And learn how to use relational databases. And through data modeling technology, combined with business models and operating policies to establish a complete accounting information system. At the same time, it can effectively use the concept of relational database and the structure of a relational database to strengthen the internal control of the accounting information system.
(4) After an in-depth understanding of revenue cycle operating policies and business processes, discuss how the chief financial officer, accountants, and internal auditors can design accounting information systems within the corporate revenue cycle and build a complete internal control system.
(5) Discuss the relationship and core technologies of the Internet and cryptography.
(6) Discuss cryptography, the correlation and core technology of blockchain and smart contracts.
(7) Discuss the correlation and core technology of big data, quantum computing, and artificial intelligence.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topic 1: Information system, internal control, and enterprise risk management
Topic 2: Information system control: general control and application control
Topic 3: Accounting system design: relational database and information system construction
Topic 4: Accounting information system and internal control: revenue cycle
Topic 5: Internet and encryption technology
Topic 6: Blockchain and smart contracts
Topic 7: Big data, quantum computing and artificial intelligence

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Accounting Data Analytics and Business Intelligence
courses.description:
While the production of data is expanding at an astonishing pace, companies are on average using only a fraction of the data out there. Recent survey by IMA (Institute of Management Accountants) in 2016 reveals significant skill gaps in many areas employers need most, especially identifying key data trends, data mining and extraction, operational analysis, technological acumen, statistical modeling and data analysis. This course targets towards accounting students who are interested in getting hands-on experience with data analytics and rising to the challenges and opportunities big data presents to the profession.

The course will provide a basis for handling and analyzing large-scale data stored within and outside an organization and finding business insights from analyses. In the first two-thirds of the course, we will study the basic concepts and techniques related to data preprocessing, data exploration, model building and results interpretation. Instead of digging deep into technical details, the course will provide a broad survey of common approaches and focus on the pragmatic implementation of data analytics. In the latter one-third of the course, we will discuss the emerging trends in big data and their applications in the accounting profession as well as other industries. The course will try to utilize real datasets related to accounting and finance and enable students to “learn by doing” through hands-on experience with data.

Prerequisites:
Students who take the course need a basic background of statistics. Having a passion for learning new things is important for the course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Accountancy and Executive Master of Professional Accountancy.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking the course, students should:
(1) Understand the basic concepts and techniques for data analytics
(2) Learn to approach business problems data-analytically
(3) Be able to choose the appropriate tools and methods for different data analysis tasks at hand and implement simple tasks in data analysis, with an understanding of their limitations
(4) Be capable of interacting competently on the topic of data analytics and collaborating with other colleagues in a data analysis project
(5) Be prepared to deal with new trends in analytics techniques affecting businesses and seize the future opportunities brought by “big data” to the accounting profession
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction & Review of Statistics
2. Data Manipulation and Preprocessing
3. Descriptive Analytics & Visualization
4. Unsupervised Learning
5. Predictive Analytics - Linear Regression
6. Predictive Analytics - Classification
7. Advanced Supervised Learning / Causal Inference
8. Web Scraping and Textual Analysis
9. Emerging Technologies
10. Big Data and Its Applications
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: To be assigned by course teacher
courses.recommended_readings: EMC Education Services (2015) Data Science and Big Data Analytics: Discovering, Analyzing, Visualizing and Presenting Data (electronic version likely available at library)

courses.title: Predictive Analytics in Accounting and Quantamental Investing
courses.description: This course explores the use of financial and non-financial data in the capital market contexts. Students will gain exposure to different data analytics techniques and predictive models to predict fundamentals and bankruptcies, to detect accounting fraud, and to identify trading strategies based on accounting anomalies. Students will gain knowledge and hands-on experience in applying these techniques generate value from accounting data.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Blockchain Technology for Accounting
courses.description:
This course aims to provide students with fundamental yet comprehensive knowledge of blockchain technology. Students who wish to explore what blockchain technology’s potential applications are and how they can change the accounting industry are encouraged to take this course. By the end of the course, students are expected to appreciate and reflect on their role as a professional accountant and be ready for the upcoming transition to the new business environment.

In the first building block, we introduce the history and fundamentals of blockchain technology. Although technical, this part is essential to establish a foundation to understand the capabilities and limitations of blockchain technology. The programming assignment will give practical experience of interacting with blockchain technology.

In the second building block, we discuss the practical applications of blockchain technology, such as how to buy, mine, store, and use cryptocurrencies, enterprise applications of blockchain (e.g., decentralized applications (DApps) and decentralized finance (DeFi)), and the future of artificial intelligence (AI) and metaverse. Industry experts and entrepreneurs will give guest lectures on the real-world blockchain applications and interact with students.

In the final building block, we discuss the accounting policies related to valuing and accounting for various crypto assets. We will also discover the regulatory risk and opportunities of the crypto markets in Hong Kong, Mainland China, and the US. The course concludes by exploring how blockchain technology can shape the future landscape of the accounting industry.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Accountancy
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:

* Understand the basic concepts and technologies of blockchain
* Understand and evaluate various blockchain applications and how those would affect accounting and auditing practices
* Understand and appreciate how blockchain technology has the potential to impact various aspects of our society, and how it can open the door to many entrepreneurial opportunities
courses.course_syllabus:
TOPICS

* *BLOCK 1: Technical Fundamentals**

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Big Data and Quantamental Investing
courses.description:
From a long-term perspective, Quantamental Investing in capital markets, especially in the A-share market, has vast development prospects. This course focuses on equity quantitative investment starting from company fundamentals, emphasizing quantitative investment strategies based on financial analysis. The goal is to provide students with a theoretical framework and practical guidance for fundamental quantitative investment, contributing to the cultivation of investment talent in the Chinese capital market.
Specifically, this course will be divided into three parts. The first part introduces the basic methods and logic of financial analysis. Grounded in fundamental principles, quantitative investment models differ from models based on statistical arbitrage or high-frequency trading, with a crucial emphasis on understanding fundamentals. The second part introduces the main alpha factors: value factor, quality factor, and momentum factor etc. The value factor exploits investors' cognitive biases to identify undervalued stocks, the quality factor evaluates company performance to find stocks expected to generate value appreciation, while the momentum factor identifies stocks with continued price increases due to insufficient investor reactions to information. Both the value and quality factors require a rigorous foundation in fundamental analysis, reflecting the modern concept of value investing (value + quality), while the momentum factor serves as an effective measure of investor sentiment. The third part introduces the basic methods of fundamental quantification, including factor evaluation in multi-factor models, backtesting, weight allocation, risk control, and dynamic adjustments—these are at the forefront of both theoretical and practical aspects. Additionally, this part will demonstrate how to implement and test these alpha strategies using professional software.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Executive Master of Professional Accountancy
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Quantamental Investing: Theoretical Framework
2. Utilizing Big Data for Financial Statement Analysis (Datayes)
3. Residual Income Model – One-click Calculation of Company Value (RIM Model)
Earnings Characteristics and Earnings Quality (M-score)
4. Classic Investment Strategies on Wall Street (WWOW)
Quantamental Investing (Alpha Research): Theory and Methods
5. Group Project Presentation (Part One)
"The Magic Formula" and Portfolio Construction (Portfolio123)
6. Investment Practice: Alpha Research Using Uqer Quant
Value Investing: The Perfect Integration of Theory and Practice
7. Hybrid Strategies: Comprehensive Implementation of the Stock Selection Strategies in Quantitative Investment Systems (Barra)
Fundamental Quantitative Investment and Its Practice in China (Inviting industry experts as the guest speaker)
8. Group Project Presentation (Part Two)

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Taxation in China
courses.description: This course is designed to familiarize students with the Chinese tax law and practice. After an introduction to the normative and institutional backgrounds of tax administration, it will examine the country’s major state and local tax regimes. The course will also touch on administrative and professional aspects of tax practice in this emerging market economy.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Accountancy; or MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:
a) Understand some major tax issues and problems on a cross-border basis
b) Analyze and solve international tax matters in light of relevant rules, regulations and practices
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to the background of China taxation
• tax structure
• tax law classification
• tax administration
• principles of international taxation
• tax treaties
• common tax planning techniques
2. China’s turnover taxes
• value-added tax (VAT) and consumption tax
• the two taxes’ nature
• subject matters
• types of taxpayers and their treatments
• tax rates
• computation
• tax credit system
• tax concessions and export related issues
3. Individual and enterprise income taxes
• types of taxpayers
• the scope of tax liability
• taxable income
• sources & rate
• deductions
• treatment of assets
• double taxation and foreign tax credit
• controlled foreign corporations
• latest income tax development
4. Transfer pricing
5. An overview of tax havens
• information exchanges and OECD efforts of dealing with base erosion and profit shifting problems

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: International Taxation Planning and Management
courses.description: This course introduces the tax concern of cross-border economic activities. It introduces the key concepts of international taxation, such as the tax jurisdiction of residence and source, international double taxation, relief from double taxation under domestic law and double taxation agreements. It also examines measures to prevent international tax avoidance, procedural mechanisms by which international tax issues are resolved, and bilateral administrative issues.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in Master of Accountancy
Prerequisite: ACCT5160 Taxation and Tax Planning
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
(1) Identify and assess the tax risks of cross-border activities.
(2) Understand the policies for taxing international transactions and the principles of company and personal taxation applicable to the taxation of inbound and outbound transactions.
(3) Understand the relief from double taxation under domestic law and double taxation agreements.
(4) Identify and apply common types of anti-avoidance provisions designed to counter specified forms of international tax planning.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Basic principles of international taxation
• Rules for determining residence and source
• Taxation of residents
• Taxation of non-residents
• Relief from double taxation under domestic law and double taxation agreements
• Relief from double taxation under double taxation agreements
• International tax planning
• International anti-tax avoidance measures
• Thin capitalisation regulations
• Controlled foreign corporation rules
• Foreign investment fund rules
• Transfer pricing
• Current issues in international taxation

2. Students are warmly welcomed to provide comments/feedback on the course by sending e-mails to the course instructor and/or making appointments with the course instructor.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Corporate Tax Planning and Risk Management
courses.description: The course is designed for students to learn the evolution of the tax system from a historical perspective, and its relation with the political and economic systems. Topics include: 1) measuring daily tax compliance, 2) controlling for tax risk, 3) maximizing shareholder benefits and corporate after-tax profits, 4) minimizing tax burden through organizational structure, business model, and operating model, 5) using BEPS in cross-border investment and business processes, 6) maximizing corporate value and personal wealth by circumventing CRS constraints.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Executive Master of Professional Accountancy
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completion of this course, students are expected to be able to:
(1) understand the tax system and its relation with the political and economic systems
(2) understand tax operations, tax compliance and tax risk control
(3) understand how to maximize shareholder benefits and corporate value by minimizing tax burden of the organization
courses.course_syllabus:
Course syllabus:
(1) Historical perspective
- History of the US tax system
- Evolution of the tax system in the Han, Song and Ming dynasties, and New China
(2) Corporate tax compliance and risk control
- Requirement of "five-in-one" model
- Specific requirements for compliance
- Establishment of risk control system
- Construction of tax risk model
(3) Tax planning measures
- Construction of organizational structure
- Choice of business model
- Operation mode processing
- Use of financial means
- Cross-border tax planning

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Corporate Governance: A Global Perspective
courses.description: The OECD Guidelines for Corporate Governance identify four elements namely objectives, transparency, benchmarks and accountability as key factors that transcend both legal and national boundaries. As a concept it delineates the rights and responsibilities of each group of stakeholders in the company by providing for appropriate checks and balance to be incorporated into the process of performance, decision making and monitoring. This course will address issues within in the rubric of corporate governance from an accounting and legal perspective.

a) Understand the important institutional and human factors in business operations
b) Understand different governance issues and practices globally especially in the emerging markets such as China and Asia
c) Know how to address and resolve some important corporate governance issues

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Applied Corporate Governance for Capital Markets
courses.description:
This course equips the students with a deeper understanding of the current state of play as regards corporate governance principles and rules, and the institutions through which corporate governance rules are applied to capital market participants, with a special focus on the Hong Kong and mainland China capital markets, but also addresses the challenges and trends in the real-life market place and how the linkages between effective enterprise governance, risk management and compliance can contribute to superior business performance and thereby to enhanced investor confidence in the capital markets.

Many diverse topics which impact how corporate governance is applied in practice in the capital markets, such as increasing regulatory supervision, GRC, key capital market participants, changes in the structure of the auditing profession, hot business transformation trends, a new enterprise business model, etc, are brought to life in an interlinking way using case studies and visiting business leaders to brief students and answer their questions.

Students are encouraged throughout the course to think about practical solutions to enhance corporate governance practices in Hong Kong and mainland China’s capital markets.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For Master of Accountancy students
courses.learning_outcomes:
On completion of this course, students are expected to be able to:
1. Demonstrate a deep understanding of the major corporate governance issues around the world;
2. Apply basic economic theories and logic to critically analyze corporate governance issues; and
3. Communicate their analysis and findings in an effective way.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Introduction of corporate governance
• International corporate governance
• Ownership structure and corporate governance in China
• Corporate governance mechanisms (1) - board of director
• Corporate governance mechanisms (2) - executive compensation and incentives
• Corporate governance mechanisms (3) - financial reporting and disclosures, auditing
• Corporate governance mechanisms (4) - the market for corporate control; institutional and activist investors
• Corporate governance mechanisms (5) - financial analysts, media, and regulators
• Corporate social responsibilities and socially responsible investment

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Corporate Governance: An East Asia Perspective
courses.description:
This course identifies the corporate governance challenges for companies in China and East Asia, and explores various mechanisms for strengthening their governance systems. We pay particular attention to the corporate governance issues of state-owned firms and entrepreneurial / family-controlled firms, which are prevalent in China and East Asia.

The course adopts a multi-disciplinary approach, using theories from economics, law, political science and sociology, to provide a theoretical framework for understanding the different ownership structures and corporate governance systems around the world. Combining theories with practical knowledge of corporate governance practice, we tackle issues such as government intervention on state and non-state firms, accounting opacity and fraud, ineffective board monitoring, expropriation of controlling owners against minority shareholders, and succession in family firms.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in EMBA (Chinese)
courses.learning_outcomes:
By completion of the course, students would be able to:
1) understand how various country institutions such as the political economy, legal systems and social norms shape the corporate governance and accounting systems across countries
2) analyze how firms’ corporate governance and accounting systems, which are shaped by their own country institutions, operate across countries
3) identify the challenges and analyze the effectiveness of corporate governance and accounting systems of listed firms across countries, with a focus in Asia and China
courses.course_syllabus: The course will start with a discussion on the recent corporate governance issues in the U.S. and the general theories from economics, finance and law underpinning the study of corporate governance. This is followed by a discussion of how country institutions such as political economy, legal system, and culture and social norms shape firms’ corporate governance around the world. We then focus on East Asia and China, exploring the unique institutional factors that shape their governance systems. We will identify the governance systems’ key advantages and challenges, understand the theoretical reasoning behind the systems and discuss solutions to these governance challenges.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: Detailed class notes, and four to five cases, all developed by the instructor.
courses.recommended_readings: The instructor will occasionally recommend articles from business publications including Xin Pao, The New Fortune, Cai Jin, Cai Xin, The 21st Century Economic Report, The Asian Wall Street Journal, The South China Morning Post, The Economist, Business Week, and so forth.

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: ESG and Accounting

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04

courses.description: This course helps students to understand and analyse ESG issues from the perspective of corporations and the capital markets. Course topics include reasons for the popularity of ESG issues in the business world; core elements of ESG and how they are measured; current reporting requirements and reporting practices; the impact of ESG on firm value; and ESG investing strategies. The course emphasizes critical thinking and uses a combination of lectures and cases.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Accountancy, Executive Master of Professional Accountancy or MSc in Sustainable Global Business
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking the course, students are expected to

· Explain the importance of ESG for businesses and investors

· Understand the connection of ESG issues to accounting and finance

· Describe how the key elements of ESG are measured and rated

· Describe international standards of ESG reporting and reporting practice of corporations worldwide

· Evaluate firms’ incentives of conducting and disclosing CSR/ESG activities

· Analyse the impact of different types of ESG on firm value

· Describe common ESG investment strategies

· Analyse material ESG and sustainability issues for selected companies.

1. Nature of ESG

· Why do companies and investors care about ESG

· Why is ESG becoming so popular nowadays

2. Current status of ESG practice – international comparison

· Social

· Governance

3. ESG reporting standards

4. ESG reporting practice – international evidence

· U.S.

5. ESG measurement and rating

6. ESG Investment

7. Climate change and financial disclosure

8. Special topics

courses.subject: ACCT
courses.title: Accounting and Management Planning for Enterprises
courses.description:
“What distinguishes the successful entrepreneur and promoter from other people is precisely the fact that he does not let himself be guided by what was and is, but arranges his affairs on the ground of his opinion about the future. He sees the past and present as other people do; but he judges the future in a different way." (Human Action, Ludwig von Mises, 1966)

Entrepreneurial activities have become a potent source of economic power that generates enormous job opportunities and business innovation globally. This is particularly spectacular in the context of China where there are numerous cases of successful and failure cases of privately owned enterprises and collectively owned township and village enterprises growing from an embryonic stage into a larger firm. The course adopts a “life-cycle” approach and develops a set of accounting and managerial skills to analyze companies from the start-up stage to eventually cashing out.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master in Accountancy
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to:
1. Understand how to get started with their new venture including:
• Generating business idea to formulating a business plan
• Organizing and financing a new venture
2. Be familiar with the accounting cycle of strategic and business planning
3. Understand more the importance of cost management and budgeting from the perspective of private equity funds
4. Be familiar with the fundamental equation of business including the introduction of an entrepreneurial capital budgeting model and important consideration like capital structure and leverage
5. Consider exit mechanism and strategies for the new venture

Financial aspects of strategic and business planning

Financial aspects of strategic and business planning

Organizational design and financial contracting

Growing a firm – internally

• Capital structure and leverage
Financing tools

External expansion – M&A

Exit mechanism and strategies
